Plan Six-Hour Strike For Prime Day; China's Economy Slows Down; Google Under Fire; ICE Launches Nationwide Roundup Of Undocumented Immigrants; Lashana Lynch Replacing James Bond As Next 007; Investor Peter Thiel Calling For Federal Investigation Into Google2019-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:35ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTMitch Roschelle, Dick Bove, Ronica Cleary, Ken CuccinelliNEWSFinancial071503cb.231Citigroup Beats Estimates; President Donald Trump Tweets on China's Second Quarter Economic Growth; Amazon Workers In M.N. Plan Six-Hour Strike For Prime Day; China's Economy Slows Down; Google Under Fire; ICE Launches Nationwide Roundup Of Undocumented Immigrants; Lashana Lynch Replacing James Bond As Next 007; Investor Peter Thiel Calling For Federal Investigation Into GoogleDagen McDowell, Ashley Webster, Deirdre Bolton, Edward Lawrence, Jeff Flock, Susan Li, Jackie DeAngelis, Stuart Varney; Cheryl Casone

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Breakings news, Citigroup earnings out. Ashley Webster has everything you need to know, Ashley.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Well, I wish I did, Dagen. I got most of the headlines here. But I don't have the adjusted earnings per share. But I can tell you, revenue coming in at 18.76 billion that is slightly better than was expected. And look at the premarket on Citigroup, up, well, $0.53, it's up 1-1/2 percent coming back just a little bit.

The banks actually have had a better time this year. They got hammered at the end of last year, but Citi is already up 38 percent this year. But here we go, we have 195 on the EPS, is that correct? And that means that's a -- that is a nice beat on the earnings front. The estimate was for 181 guys, the actual was 195. So, positive news for Citigroup. The first big financial company out of the gate on second-quarter earnings, up more than one percent in premarket.

We know, we were warned about a month ago that fixed income and equity trading revenue are going to be down in the mid-single digits. What people will be looking for is how they did in Asia concerns about the trade dispute with China did actually helped Citigroup. There are many countries in Asia. Maybe more business was picked up as companies leave China to go to other Asian countries.

But overall, first blush Dagen, not bad. At least certainly on the headline numbers. But it's been a tough goal, we know the interest rates are low, so banks are not making much money that nimb, be net interest margin not making a whole lot of money on loans with those interest rates so low.

MCDOWELL: Right, you charge more on loans than what you pay in deposit.

WEBSTER: Right.

MCDOWELL: So when you, you know, with the longer -- like longer term rates sinking, in anticipation that the Federal Reserve is going to cut rates shortly, that's potentially squeezed --

WEBSTER: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: -- certainly squeezed the margins there. But again, a beat on the top line and a beat on the bottom line. Ashley Webster, thank you so much.

WEBSTER: My pleasure.

MCDOWELL: Le's bring in Rafferty Capital Markets' chief financial strategist, Dick Bove for his reaction.

Dick, have you gotten a chance to listen to what Ashley was talking about? Even take a peek at these numbers here for Citi.

DICK BOVE, CHIEF FINANCIAL STRATEGIST, RAFFERTY CAPITAL MARKET: You know, I apologize, I haven't seen numbers at all.

MCDOWELL: That's OK.

BOVE: And I get my computer focused on it. But the point is that Citigroup and the other banks should have a decent quarter. They should have good quarter because, you know, you have to look not at the interest rate, you have to look at what they're selling, right? And in the quarter, you know, what they sell primarily are loans and loans, you know we're decent in the second quarter. You had good results from commercial industrial side, you know, you had mortgages, you know, picked up somewhat. You know, consumers are borrowing money like crazy through their credit cards and they're also, you know, coming back in the auto loan sector.

So, if you have unit volume increasing and interest rates really haven't changed yet even though they're expected to change, then your margins should be relatively stable and if they're stable when basically your earnings should be up. In addition, you know, you've had basically some very big IPOs this quarter, you had, you know, the yield curve go down right across the board, which actually creates a fortune in profit for the banks. Because remember, they have $3.5 trillion in securities that they own.

So, if you get the whole yield curve dropping, you know, you are seeing a big increase, you know, hundreds of billions of dollars in profits for the banking industry. So, you know, this should be a decent quarter. The problem is nobody will care. And the reason they won't care is because they're going to focus, focus, focus on, you know, what's going to happen with interest rates at the Fed and they -- taking the opinion that if interest rates go down, it's bad for banks, even though there is no historical evidence whatsoever to indicate that that statement is true.

So, I don't know. My guess is you ought to be buying Citigroup, you ought to be buying banks but the market's going to be very skittish about these companies.

MCDOWELL: Dick, you've always said this, that these companies that if the economy and the borrower and the consumer is healthy, that's one of the most critical things to pay attention to.

And I'll turn to a quote from Citigroup, and its earnings announcement, quote, we have good momentum in solid growth across our consumer franchise particularly in the U.S. We navigated in uncertain environment successfully by executing our strategy and by showing disciplined expense credit and risk management, this is according to Citigroup's curbing.

BOVE: You know, if you take a look at the way they've reshaped the company, right? They've gotten rid of, you know, most of their foreign involvement, getting out of you know, countries all around the world. They've closed down businesses in the United States, they've eliminated the deposit facilities all over United States, and they've got -- let's say, two really, really strong trust.

One is, they still are a dominant credit company around credit card company around the world. And the credit card business looks great right now, it looks great because, you know, earnings are up slightly for individuals in real terms and obviously, jobs are up significantly.

The second business that they focused on, is trading in investment banking. And while trading always goes down in the second quarter versus the first quarter, from the seasonal standpoint, you know, investment banking has been terrific, right? I mean, investment banking, you've got all of these companies that came to market, they're prices went up. Therefore, the green shoes are extraordinarily profitable for companies who are part of this indication.

So, again, you know, you should see decent numbers coming out of banks this quarter. And if you take a look at what the banks do, relative to what supposedly the S&P 500 is going to do. The banks are going to show up earnings and the S&P is going to be flat to down according to other people, I don't make that forecast. If that's true, then the banks should be bought in addition to which the multiples on bank stocks are very low. But the problem is nobody cares about anything I just said, all they care about is what did Me. Powell -- Chairman Powell say to the Senate and House last week. What is going to happen to interest rates, and that's just -- it's a farce because what happens to interest rates is not going to kill banks.

MCDOWELL: But I will point out, Citigroup stock is up 38 percent here today which is wildly outperforming kind of your broad market gauges, even the S&P 500 here. Mitch, you have a question for Dick.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC CHARITABLE FOUNDATION: (INAUDIBLE) that's almost two times of the S&P as they grow.

MCDOWELL: Right.

ROSCHELLE: If they're not going to care about bank stocks, they're not going to care about the answer to this question either, which is one of the things that was a big talking point in the earnings calls of all of the banks after the first quarter was expenses and then this press release, they even talked expenses. Are banks really cutting back their spend and is that really part of what's driving the earnings? Obviously, the revenue's up, but earnings per share is up but are expense control big part of the equation here, Dick?

BOVE: Oh, yes, absolutely, you're definitely correct, a hundred percent. I mean, basically, technology, you know, people think that another false impression about banks is that they lying in technology. Banks are the most advanced companies in technology in the United States, other than the technology companies themselves. And they've used that technology, extraordinarily effectively to replace labor-intensive activities with machines.

And as a result of that, you know, their expenses are not growing. You know, their loan losses are going to creep up, but the loan losses are extraordinarily low. So, a huge part of the story on banks over the last few years has been the fact that their expenses don't go up, and their revenues eke up, you know, in small amounts which leads to, you know, relatively good increases in pretax income.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Dick, I want to ask you, its Deirdre. Quickly, you mentioned the investment banking as a strength which obviously it is. And we expect to hear from its peers of course through the week.

But what do you make of more and more companies going public with direct listings? And Spotify was the first to do it that's not been a loan, and seems like more and more companies are going to be doing this which essentially means just cutting out the middle man, in this case, investment bankers. Are all -- is this business being disrupted? Or are we looking at a few companies that have just chosen to go public differently?

BOVE: Well, the whole -- you're right Deirdre, the whole structure of the market has changed, right? In other words, you got private equity companies, you've got money flowing in from overseas, so that the need to go to a big bank to do a public offering for you is becoming significantly reduced.

However, you know, you get all these unicorns which are coming to market that don't have any profits, perhaps they never had profits. And you do -- you do need someone to sell that story. And in order to get someone to sell that story, you do have to go to a big bank, and these big banks I think have done an extraordinarily effective job for themselves, and the shareholders in this past quarter and I think that will show up when all of these numbers are out for Citi and J.P. Morgan and Goldman and Morgan Stanley and all of these guys.

MCDOWELL: Dick, good to see you this morning, thank you so much. Dick Bove, joining us.

BOVE: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Turning to U.S.-China trade, the president speaking out this morning on China's economic growth in the second quarter. Edward Lawrence, live at the White House with the very latest. Good morning, Ed.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Dagen. Yes, the president woke up with the economy on his mind. His first set of tweets on that talking about how he's talking about the antiquated -- his words, the antiquated policy of the Federal Reserve, but we are still growing. He says, much room to grow for the U.S. economy, then the president turned to China. The president saying that Chinese have had the slowest growth they've had in 27 years as of right now. The president pointing to the fact that tariffs are playing a major role in that economy, also, playing a major role in the fact that companies are trying to leave China for nontariff companies.

The president going on on Twitter to say that China has wished that it did not break the deal that it made with the United States, the president making the case, that China's actually paying for the tariffs which is something you said before by devaluing pumping money into their system here. The president holding off though on everything else the China imports into the United States placing that under tariff, although that still is an option for the president. Now right now, the talks on the phone are still happening between the two trade groups, the U.S. trying to get a date for the next round of face-to-face talks.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PETER NAVARRO, DIRECTOR, TRADE AND MANUFACTURING POLICY: Now, we're facing a country that hacks our computers, that steals our intellectual property, forces technology transfer, manipulates (INAUDIBLE) its currency and dumps fentanyl into our communities. So, those are the kinds of things we're trying to negotiate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And Peter Navarro there, that went out see economic adversaries on that trade council, the greater council that's trying to negotiate with this. They're also trying to gauge how amenable the Chinese will be when they come back to the talks to see what the concessions that they had made and taken out of the deal will be placed back into a trade deal, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Edward Lawrence, at the White House.

Coming up, Louisiana underwater, we take you live to New Orleans for a closer look at how that city is recovering from tropical depression Barry.

And Prime Day protest, activist taking action against Amazon as the retail giant kicks off its global shopping event. How your deals could be affected.

MCDOWELL: Barry making landfall in Louisiana over the weekend. It's weakened into tropical depression, but still brings the threat of flooding and heavy rain.

Fox Business's Jeff Flock is live in New Orleans with the very latest. Good morning, Jeff.

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Dagen, good morning to you. They prepared for the worst and hoped for best, and well, they got what they hoped for. This is -- this is New Orleans in Mississippi, and maybe you see.

But I think -- I don't think you can tell, you know, you have had a hurricane coming in with river at record high levels for this time of year. In fact, to give indication how high it is, there's a -- there's a marker out there that is on dry land.

And actually, you see how much the Mississippi has come in. But despite that, it wasn't as bad as they thought. Yes, there were some overtopping of levees. Take a lot at a picture from Plaquemines Parish, south of here. There was an overtop there, a couple of others. But there's a big difference between overtop and a failure, failure means big floods.

Outside the levee system, though, yes, there was flooding, and we got pictures of some of the rescues that took place. Some people from roofs of their houses. But these are people that live in low-lying areas, and probably, should not have stayed in the face of this hurricane anyway.

I leave you, Dagen, perhaps with a picture of New Orleans, a block little by a tree here, but if Frank takes a look down there, there are 224 floodgates in New Orleans. That's one of them there. They closed them all, they're now in the process of reopening them. And that one leading into the French Quarter, right there open protected the city.

Did they learn something from Katrina? By gosh, I think they did. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Jeff, good to see you my friend. Jeff Flock in New Orleans.

FLOCK: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, taking action against Amazon. Protesters rallying against Prime Day as the retail giant kicks off its annual global shopping event. How this would impact your deals?

Plus, big tech threat. Billionaire Peter Thiel, calling for an FBI investigation and the CIA into Google, over its relationship with China. More details on that.

MCDOWELL: Amazon Prime Day, online shoppers getting two days of deals. While Amazon employees in Minnesota plan to go on strike. Susan Lee is covering a story live from Minneapolis. Good morning, Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning to you, Dagen. That's right. So, Christmas and July, with Amazon kicking off its two-day Prime Day events where they are expected to bring in around $4 billion to $7 billion over the next 48 hours.

But given the success of Amazon, it's really become a political flashpoints. They make billions of dollars of the U.S. consumer. And some say, they don't pay their fair share when it comes to corporate taxes and they don't treat their workers as good as they should.

Now, we are here just outside Minneapolis, and we are expecting a first-of- its-kind workers strike on one of the most important days for Amazon. Now, this is not the first worker protests we've seen here at this fulfillment center. In fact, one took place in December last year.

But, we are expecting one for one of the most important days for Amazon here on this prime day. And speaking it to us this morning, we're catching up with Meg Brady who's one of the Amazon workers and part of -- I would say part of the organizing as well in this -- in this protest. We're expecting 100 workers to go on strike. I'm just wondering, what are they protesting?

MEG BRADY, WORKER, AMAZON: Well, working at Amazon is really difficult. It's very hard place to work. And one of the things that would reduce some of the stresses if management would reduce the rates, the production rates that were required to meet every hour.

LI: That's right. So, we're talking about productivity quotas, meeting the number of packages you need to pack up within an hour. And here, it's at 600, whether they're big or small. And some say that seems a little unfair, right?

BRADY: Right, in my particular job at 600 items an hour I handle, and we also would like to see some improvements made in ergonomics, because the repetitive nature of our work leads to workplace injuries.

LI: That's why, in fact, you are on medical leave yourself.

BRADY: That's correct.

LI: Yes, were you injured here at this Amazon fulfillment center?

BRADY: I was. Yes.

LI: Yes. And so, a reduction. How big of a reduction are you looking for? What would be fair to you?

BRADY: I would say, even a 10 percent reduction in rate across the board would help workers quite a bit.

LI: Yes. So, just a 10 percent reduction. So that's just around 540 packages an hour, down from the 600. That's what you're looking for?

BRADY: Right, and then, in my particular case, the rates do vary depending on what position you're in.

LI: Yes, and another issue that workers are protesting is the fact that they are hiring more temporary staff, and not giving up full-time positions.

BRADY: Right, the temporary workers, they are held to the same standards that full-time Amazon employees are held to. But yet, they don't have Amazon benefits.

LI: Right, but just to give the other side of this story. We did get in contact with Amazon. They say that 90 percent of the workers here at this fulfillment center are full-time staff.

BRADY: Right, well, the integrity's workers are full-time but they're still not employees.

LI: Yes.

BRADY: Amazon, please.

LI: But what I'm hearing from you is it's -- I guess about the working conditions and also the full-time positions. It's not about money, because Amazon has moved up their minimum wage to $15 an hour.

In fact, they told us here at this particular fulfillment center, the average wage is around $16 to $20 with benefits.

BRADY: That's correct. I make $17.15 an hour.

LI: Yes, and what about unionization then? Are you getting pushback in terms of forming one by Amazon?

BRADY: Right. Amazon is anti-union. I, personally, I'm a pro-union. That's not really what we're protesting today, but that could be something that we look at in the future.

LI: Yes, and it's not just the workers here at this fulfillment center, I believe a pilot, it's coming to join, and also some of that well-paid engineers in Seattle flying here as well.

BRADY: Right. We have quite a show of support from other co-workers.

LI: Yes, but why Prime Day? I mean, why not select another day? Is this -- I guess, to make your message heard more loudly?

BRADY: Yes, and normally, if there's a disruption in work, they would transfer the work to another fulfillment center. But that's not possible today because all the fulfillment centers are busy.

LI: And what would you like Jeff Bezos to hear from you? He is the richest man in the world and he, of course, is the founder and owner of Amazon.

BRADY: Well, management demands the best from its workers. And now, we want management's best.

LI: OK, Meg, Meg, thank you so much. Great to see you.

BRADY: Thank you.

LI: And so, we are expecting the six-hour walkout just to take place in the afternoon. So, at the end of the day's session, and then, heading into the night session as well. And as I mentioned to you, Dagen, first-of-its- kind because workers usually don't go on strike when it's this busy. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Susan, thank you for that. Susan Lee in Minneapolis. Amazon Prime Day, two days. Mitch, have you been looking at this like to impact on the business? Like -- because I raised the issue with one of our earlier guests with Charlie O'Shea that is it -- is that Prime Day phenomenon losing its oomph, but maybe it's given oomph to these other retailers like Wal-Mart and Target. Best to take advantage of it.

ROSCHELLE: I think it's helping the entire retail ecosystem whether or not it's digital or in store, and going back to something we were talking about earlier, is the consumer is very, very strong right now, and that's the component of our economy that is probably the strongest, no better time than when the consumer strong to create retail buying opportunities.

So, but I think prime day is a great sort of catalyst to sort of get people to think about shopping. Six months away from the busiest time of the year for shopping. So, that's why they do it.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Yes, just reminds people, right? Reminds people, if you haven't been on Amazon past 48 hours, here you go. Here's the deal.

BOLTON: There you go, Mitch.

MCDOWELL: Lots of amazon the Amazon -- the Amazon products like the deals on the echo of Dyson vacuum. There you go.

BOLTON: Well, I think Amazon wants people to be addicted to its ecosystem much as a lot of people are with Apple. So, when you talk about Amazon offering, echoes and anything that's run by Alexa. And, of course, we've heard that they're developing kind of mini robot, right? They want you to use their services as much as the shopping.

ROSCHELLE: And they're also creating products like the video doorbell and stuff that tie-into all of their other products.

BOLTON: Right. Yes.

ROSCHELLE: And because what's next, especially, when we get into a 5G world is the Internet of things where all of these devices are connected to one another.

RONICA CLEARY, PRESIDENT, CLEARY STRATEGIES: You know, it may -- it may not affect the woman that we just heard with Susan, but there was a report out last week -- I mean, Amazon is spending $700 million to train their workforce in light of a third of their workforce in response to automation.

To give their workforce a better ability to adapt to how technology is changing things. Because that fulfillment center, that's -- that woman works in, I mean that may not exist with any humans working in it in so many years.

ROSCHELLE: Right.

CLEARY: So, there is some sort of response maybe not direct, but there is a responsible on part of the company to --

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Well, that's a good point, contracting an effort even because it cost them money to replace workers.

CLEARY: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: Right.

MCDOWELL: Again, this falls on the private sector rather than politicians who have been talking and doing nothing. Not walking the talk for literally decades in this country. You know, again, it comes down to what are these private businesses doing to make -- to make sure that it their own workforces are trained and retrained and modern and current.

ROSCHELLE: And relevant for the skills that are needed to drive the businesses in the future.

MCDOWELL: Right, yes.

ROSCHELLE: It's a lot cheaper to train your existing talent that they go out and replace them with new ones.

MCDOWELL: Yes, absolutely. Thank you all. Coming up, it -- curbing illegal immigration. President Trump's large-scale nationwide raids against undocumented immigrants not unfolding that way so far.

And targeting tech, billionaire Peter Thiel said to be calling for an investigation into Google over its relationship with China.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, July 15th, your top stories at 8:30 a.m. Eastern.

Markets poised for a higher open looking to push new all-time highs at 52 gain on Dow Futures. All three major market gauges in the green following a record-setting week for the Dow, NASDAQ and S&P.

Citigroup with the double beat profits rising on lower cost and gains in consumer lending. The news lifting Citi other banks ahead of the open. You have gains across the board Citigroup stock, it's up almost more than 35 percent year-to-date, adding nearly one percent in premarket action.

In Europe, you have buying in England, France and Germany this morning. The biggest winner there, the DAX in Germany up about half of one percent.

More signs of a slowdown in China, that was kind of -- factored into the Asian markets. China's economy growing by 6.2 percent in the second quarter, sounds strong, but it was the slowest rate since 1992, at least 92. Slowest rate on record. In Japan, the Nikkei was closed for a holiday.

Border battle. ICE going ahead nation-wide with a crackdown on illegal immigrants. This as some local leaders fight back against the raids.

Bitcoin plunging. The cryptocurrency diving more than 10 percent over the weekend, briefly trading below $10,000. This follows last week's comments from President Donald Trump saying he is not fan of Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, talking about regulation.

Plus, high-tech threat. Billionaire, Peter Thiel, reportedly calling for investigation into Google over its work with China. What these allegations could mean for the tech giant.

To our top story this half hour. A nationwide crackdown on illegal immigration. ICE action planned in 10 major cities as agents try to round up thousands of immigrants already ordered out of the country. South Carolina Senator Lindsey Graham visited the border on Friday, and Maria Bartiromo spoke with him yesterday on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" and he weighed on the raids.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We've got some pushback from some Democrats, and liberal mayors trying to stop the ICE officials and Border Patrol officials from carrying out their directive.

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC): The ICE raids today are focused on criminals who have gone to court and lost their case. Democrats are also advocating decriminalizing entry into United States and providing free health care to illegal immigrants once they get here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining me now U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services Acting Director Ken Cuccinelli. Ken, good to see you this morning.

KEN CUCCINELLI, ACTING DIRECTOR, U.S. CITIZENSHIP AND IMMIGRATION SERVICES: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: A story in the Wall Street Journal titled: Large Scale Immigration Raids Fail to Materialize reports this, "ICE agents were put on standby for potential raids this weekend and while some operations continued in individual cities, agents were never given an order to execute on a nationwide scale," one administration official says. What do you make of this? Again, it seems like the public was led to believe there was going to be something kind of massive and widespread, not happening.

CUCCINELLI: So, the way I understand that (INAUDIBLE), the Acting Director of ICE has set this up is that he has given discretion to his local responsible officers to perform their responsibility fit. Now, I'm speaking very generally, but that's the way law enforcement should operate. Law enforcement operations have to be taken on case-by-case basis if for no other reason officers' safety.

So, the notion that you're going to hear some national rollout announcement is really, I think, kind of people are, are misconstruing that. And let's remember just how far we fallen that ICE just doing their job -- so many loyal, competent, professional officers just doing their job has suddenly become news. And this is what they do every day, whether it's cracking down on employers violating our law or whether it's gathering people who are disobeying federal orders over a million people with federal removal orders who are not obeying those orders.

And they do target, as you heard Senator Graham say, they still prioritize criminals in this country, but that is not an exclusive target. Anyone in that million people who have been through massive due process and gotten removal order are subject to removal and ICE'S job is to do exactly that, they take their job very seriously, they're very good at it, despite a lot of the vitriol lobbed at them by elements of the political class.

MCDOWELL: Ken, we should point out -- I just want to make this clear -- your agency is not directly involved in law enforcement.

CUCCINELLI: Correct.

MCDOWELL: It's charged, but you administrator the country's legal immigration system.

CUCCINELLI: And asylum. Yes.

MCDOWELL: Green cards, right? Eligible asylum-seekers that's what you handle.

CUCCINELLI: Correct.

MCDOWELL: But I wondered about the wisdom of talking about these raids because President Trump started talking about them last month. He announced a similar raid last month; it was postponed amid concern over the officers' safety. And you've been asked about it and commented about the raid last week. Why give illegal immigrants in this country who would be eligible for deportation? Why give them a heads-up? It just seems -- is this just political? Is it to rattle the left? Is it to basically -- is it a political move to get the left Liberals or even Democrats in this country to seem like they're siding with illegal immigrants versus those here who are here legally?

CUCCINELLI: First of all, it is important not only that a justice system work and be just but that it be seen to work and be just. The importance of that is that people who are considering coming here who think all they've got to do is get by the border illegally, and that they're home mystery ICE stands in the way of that; they are the wall there. And when those people come in illegally, and get orders of removal, they need to know that even after that point that our legal system the rule of law still applies and that they will be removed or they're subject to removal that's who this is important for in addition to just maintaining the rule of law.

MCDOWELL: But Ken, my question is when you talk about raids that are going to happen across the country, you're giving people who might be deported a heads-up, and you're giving people the Democrats in some of these sanctuary cities a heads-up. It seems like that you're doing it for political purposes. If you were quiet, it would be easier for agents themselves to go into these communities and actually apprehend people who are here illegally, who are offered deportation and send them back to their home country.

CUCCINELLI: Well, unfortunately, this particular subject matter illegal immigration is a hot button, it is -- major subject of policy debate, and so you do get public discussion including of law enforcement operation at a general level. It should it never get specific beforehand that causes all sorts of problems. But you are right, it is discussed publicly. But what people should understand is that for those more than million people who have had due process, and have removal orders, they are always subject to this removal.

It is -- and ICE doesn't sit around say all right on x and such date, we're going to go after 1000-2000 of these people. This is a rolling effort on their part. What you've heard talked about is a broader push. But understand that ICE is doing their job every day, whether it's enforcing against employers breaking the law, whether it's people with removal orders and so on.

MCDOWELL: The mayor and police chief from Los Angeles pushed back against ICE. Listen to this, Ken.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ERIC GARCETTI, MAYOR OF LOS ANGELES: I want every Angeleno to know their rights and how to exercise them. I want you to know that you do not need be afraid; your city is on your side. And rest assured here in Los Angeles, we are not coordinating with ICE.

MICHAEL MOORE, POLICE CHIEF, LOS ANGELES: Our police force is going to do the job of federal law enforcement. Immigration is a federal matter; safety is a police matter. So, we're not going to mix those two.

GARCETTI: Plus, this is a partisan politics. It's about being a good neighbor --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Ken, your reaction to that.

CUCCINELLI: Yes, that's pathetic. That is pathetic! We're talking about people would who have been through a massive due process, and by and large broken the law to come here. And, and, remember, ICE still targets criminals -- meaning people who have committed other crimes after coming into this country. And so for the mayor and police chief of one of the largest counties in the country, largest cities in the country to speak about harboring criminals, by and large, because remember that's the priority for ICE and they proudly say we're not going to help protect those people, not 15 miles from where I sit.

Prince Georges County police in Maryland were saying same thing after MS-13 killed a 14-year-old girl and the people who killed her were illegal aliens who had previously been detained and should have been handed over to ICE. But no, Maryland proudly proclaimed itself a sanctuary state and Prince Georges County as sanctuary locality. And they proudly didn't hand these people over, and now, another girl is dead, and she was an illegal alien and she still deserve to live. The fact that it isn't just Americans who are victimized, other aliens are victimized too. ICE is protecting against that.

MCDOWELL: Horrific crimes. But my point is, is that when you have administration officials talking to the press about the upcoming raids, the upcoming raids, the upcoming raids, it turns into back-and-forth political posturing rather than just allowing these ICE agents to quietly go into these communities and apprehend these people who are here illegally, who are potential criminals, who are -- have their deportation efforts already in place. That's my point. Is that when you talk about it so publicly, it turns into this left and right back-and-forth and it's just political posturing, and actually isn't following through with the deportations into law.

CUCCINELLI: Look, there are pros and cons to being more public about this. You have just identified I think quite accurately one of the cons, one of the negatives. And as I mentioned earlier, one of the pros is that we are trying to create a deterrence effect as well because we're trying to affect future behavior, and calculus each may come to maybe a little different. You think that it shouldn't be talked about beforehand obviously, the president thinks somewhat differently weighing more in favor of the deterrent effect.

Those are honest debates that I think are legitimate to have and, of course, always prioritizing officers' safety which factors in. And obviously, the president has come out a little bit differently from how you feel about it. I try to focus maximizing the deterrence opportunities here. As you note, this is an ICE responsibility, it's not my agency. We have a lot of respect for our ICE agents and for the work they do. We want them safe as possible but we also want to take advantage of the fact to tell the rest of the world: look, this is how we operate. We enforce our laws, and you can't expect to simply ignore them if you come to America.

MCDOWELL: All right, Ken Cuccinelli thank you so much, Acting Director U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services.

CUCCINELLI: Good to be with you.

MCDOWELL: Take care. Coming up, Christmas in July. Retail giant, Amazon, kicking off its annual prime day, prime two-day shopping event. Not everyone is onboard. Stuart Varney weighs in.

And big banks in focus. Shares of Citigroup jumping up almost one percent after beating Wall Street expectation on quarterly earnings. We take you to the trading floor for a look, next.

MCDOWELL: Citigroup, the first of the big banks to report quarterly earnings, posting a beat this morning. Jackie DeAngelis on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with the details. Jackie.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning to you, Dagen. Traders watching Citi very closely this morning because kicks off the bank's earnings season, and earnings season in earnest, too. Traders wanted to hear that there's more than just a pending rate from the Fed that's going to drive stocks higher and strong earnings from the banks certainly could be it. We got earnings per share from Citigroup of $1.83. That was higher than expected on revenue $18.76 billion and so everyone will be watching. What's Bank of America going to say? What's Goldman, JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley going to say later on in the week? Meantime, they said that a jump in fixed income trading helped earnings at also cost- cutting. The conference call at 10:00 a.m., people are going to be wanting to hear what they say about their international business, specifically Asia.

I want to switch gears and take a look at shares of Google for a moment because, over the weekend, Axios reported that Peter Thiel was speaking in Washington, D.C., and he said that the FBI and CIA should actually investigate Google to see if it's been infiltrated by Chinese intelligence. Google not responding to this yet, but certainly this could open Pandora's Box, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Jackie, thank you so much for that. Jackie DeAngelis at the New York Stock Exchange. Amazon's Prime Day in full swing, online shoppers getting two days of deals while employees in Minnesota plan to go on strike. Joining me now, the host of "VARNEY & CO." Stuart Varney. Mr. Varney, what say you, sir?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I say it's Christmas in July, that's what I say. I mean, I think what Amazon has done with the -- it started, I think, in 2000 -- don't know exactly when it started, but Prime Days, it started, expanded, and grew and it is a revolution in the retailing business. Wal-Mart's joined in, Target's joined in, eBay's joined in, it starts today, 48 hours of these Prime Days, 18 countries involved, a million products will be what is it a million deals that are on offer, it just turns the retailing business on its headed, doesn't it.

It used to be Black Friday, day after Thanksgiving, or back-to-school, you could see the lines out the doors for the -- for the special offers, now it's all done online, gigantic retailing operation, Christmas in July. Frankly, I love it. But I don't think it's -- we quite understand yet how big a deal it is.

MCDOWELL: Stuart, I'm on the phone shopping for you.

VARNEY: Oh, thank you very much.

MCDOWELL: I am trying to figure out what would you buy you? Are not planning to -- you're not much, you're not really much of a shopper, but I know -- you love a deal.

VARNEY: Why do you say I am not much of a shopper?

MCDOWELL: I don't think that you're, because I think that you're very careful with your money.

VARNEY: Are you calling me cheap?

MCDOWELL: No, I'm just -- I'm -- no, not at all. But I don't think that you were a frivolous person.

VARNEY: Where's Maria? No, sorry. I know, I'm not, and you're quite right, I do have a hard time putting my hand in my pocket --

MCDOWELL: Yes.

VARNEY: -- and putting money down right there or slapping down the plastic.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

VARNEY: I have a hard time doing that.

MCDOWELL: Let other people --

VARNEY: I am thrifty.

MCDOWELL: Yes, let other people shop where you're --

VARNEY: And thrift as a virtue, young lady.

MCDOWELL: I agree, Stuart.

VARNEY: There you go.

MCDOWELL: I agree with you 100 percent all day long every day. Stuart starts in less than 10 minutes.

VARNEY: I do.

MCDOWELL: Stuart, thank you so much.

VARNEY: See you later. And reminder, "VARNEY & CO." every day, 9:00 a.m. to noon Eastern. Coming up, Facebook under the microscope, the Securities and Exchange Commission considering a crackdown on the social media giant's cryptocurrency. And casting a new bond, James Bond, Daniel Craig passing torch to a new double 007. We'll you who might be taking over that iconic role next.

MCDOWELL: Mayor lay -- major lay-offs reportedly are coming at Huawei here in the U.S. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: That's right, Dagen. The Wall Street Journal is reporting this morning that hundreds of people can be let go after the Trump administration black listed the company. CASONE: OK. This Daniel Craig is in this movie.

Corporate Participants

* Naveed Sultan

Citigroup Inc. - Global Head of Treasury & Trade Solutions

Conference Call Participants

* Susan Roth Katzke

Crédit Suisse AG, Research Division - MD & Senior Analyst

Presentation

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE, MD & SENIOR ANALYST, CRéDIT SUISSE AG, RESEARCH DIVISION: So good morning, everybody, and thank you. Thank you, Thomas, for joining us this morning. We at Crédit Suisse look forward to your leadership in the years ahead.

So as Thomas said, we're back for day 2 of our 21st Annual Crédit Suisse Financial Services Forum, and I'm pleased to kick off the day welcoming back Citigroup. I'm not just welcoming back Citigroup, I'm welcoming back Naveed Sultan, who heads up TTS, Treasury and Trade Solutions, for Citigroup. He joined us here in February of 2016. A fair bit has changed since 2016, including about 35% growth in related TTS revenue and related TTS-driven deposits if you look 2019 versus 2015.

So without further delay, let's get started here. We'll have a fireside chat, and then Naveed will be available afterwards for a breakout session.

NAVEED SULTAN, GLOBAL HEAD OF TREASURY & TRADE SOLUTIONS, CITIGROUP INC.: Thank you, Susan.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: Thank you.

NAVEED SULTAN: Good morning, everyone.

Questions and Answers

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: Okay, day 2. So let's get started, if you would, at kind of a higher level with maybe a brief overview of the TTS businesses, maybe just to level set here on size, scope, composition of the businesses.

NAVEED SULTAN: Yes. Thank you. If you think about the TTS business, it's very strategic and foundational for Citigroup's business and operating model. And we deliver a wide range of working capital management solutions to our clients around the world, leveraging our global platform. It includes products and solutions in payments area, receivable areas, liquidity management services, commercial cards, trade finance, trade services and foreign exchange.

Our engagement with the clients is wide-ranging. So we do business with corporate clients. 80%-plus Fortune 500 companies use our platform around the world, government entities; public sector entities, financial institutions, including banks; digital economy clients; the big tech; the fintech; as well as the commercial banking clients. As far as the digital economy clients are concerned, digital economy clients are on an accelerated path to globalization, and our platform is a very natural fit for them to achieve that goal.

In terms of the size and scope, we are in 98 markets where we actually have banking licenses. And in some of those markets, we have operated well over 100 years. We are connected with over 250 trading systems, including several -- on top of that, several alternative payment mechanisms and channels. So on average, we process about $4 trillion worth of flows, which could go up to, whatever, $5 trillion, $6 trillion on a big day, and that's essentially in 145 currencies around the world. And we have a market share of about 15% for the SWIFT dollar flows.

Now if you look at this business from a client perspective, it has both operating and strategic relevance. The operating relevance is that we are deeply embedded in our clients' operating environment, in their operating processes and help them do business around the world on a day-to-day basis. Strategically, because we provide working capital management solutions and help our clients become more efficient. The companies who have more efficient working capital management tend to outperform their peers on 4 critical dimensions: growth, reinvestment, dividend payout and market gap. So both from an operating and strategic standpoint, it's very, very relevant to our clients.

Now it's -- in terms of its contribution to Citi, 2019 was the sixth consecutive year of growth. We delivered about $10 billion worth of revenues, over 20% of company's net income and 45% of total company's deposits, which, as of December 31, the average was about $559 billion. And that mostly is the operating deposits. Highly efficient business, according to independent objective studies and consistently has delivered well over 20% return on equity. Last year, we grew our deposits by 10% on a constant dollar basis. And I think the correlation between the operating activity and the deposits is very, very tight and close post Basel III and all the rest of it. So therefore, it does reflect their growth in deposits, operating deposits, does reflect the growth in the underlying operating drivers.

So that's more or less -- like I said, it's a very strategic business. It's fundamental to our business and operating model.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: And so let's back up a second. Based on the numbers that you gave me, the pretax margin and the ROE are clearly above the average for Citi as a whole. How have those trended over time?

NAVEED SULTAN: The -- for the last 6 years, like I said, we have delivered 6th consecutive year of revenue growth. We have a very sharp focus on scalability and operating efficiency. And if you look at the trajectory of all the key ratios in the last 6 years, they have been a positive trajectory despite different macroeconomic environments, geopolitical context and interest rate volatility in U.S. and elsewhere in the world.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: Okay. And in terms of the deposit flows, up 10%, I think you said, last year, and we drove a number, having grown about 35% over the last 4 years. Can we talk a little bit about the key drivers of the deposits. And kind of what's going on with deposit flows? What goes on in a risk-on versus risk-off environment?

NAVEED SULTAN: I think the deposit growth is an outcome of your client engagement and your ability to continue to improve your operating drivers. So that is you are delivering your solutions to your clients around the world, they are expanding in different markets, they are going into new customer segments. And since we are so embedded into their operating processes, next market geographically or next business segment is a very logical extension of our engagement with our clients. So once that happens, you see the deposits picking up because operating liquidity is, by definition, what is needed to finance the underlying flows of a client.

Then we have been seeing -- continuously gaining more market share, not only with the existing clients but, of course, also with the new age clients. And because of the platform we have, whenever there is a consolidation in the marketplace, there is a natural gravitation towards our platform. So all those -- some new solutions, of course, new solutions. And the thing is that clients are continuously becoming more sophisticated. They are -- they need advice from partners like us to help them navigate an environment which is going through structural shifts.

The economies are in transition, finance is in transition, globalization is in transition. So if you look at, in that context, we are very compatible with how the clients want to do business globally and we assist them navigating those shifts, that leads to more business, and that creates an outcome for our liquidity, for our deposits share.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: Perfect. So you've touched on some of these elements already, but let's talk about the growth strategy with Treasury and Trade Solutions. And maybe talk about how you maintain that market leadership over time and how you maintain this, let's call it, mid-single -- mid- to high single-digit growth rate, although I don't think that you would assume that, that was a naturally sustainable growth rate for this business.

NAVEED SULTAN: Yes. Well, like I said, I mean, if you think about the nature of our network, it is -- I -- we talk about it a lot, and sometimes there are debate in the industry that some synthetic network is going to come and replace these traditional networks. But just to explain what the network is because it really gives us a very differentiated and a unique position in the marketplace.

So the network is really, first of all, 95 markets where we have banking licenses. We understand the legal and regulatory jurisdictions. We understand the business environment and risk relating to those markets. And we have very close relationship with the regulators and policymakers. And we have been a significant participant in those economies. So that's one component of our model.

The second one is that our core technology infrastructure is global and is consistent around the world. On top of that infrastructure, which is really our digital channels, online channels, our payment systems, trade systems and things of those -- commercial card systems. On top of that, we have built a very rich set of functionalities, products as well as our solutions. So that's the third component.

The fourth component is our coverage model. We in our coverage organization are organized exactly the way the client is organized. So they are in many, many markets. There are many subsidiaries, many buying centers, regional treasury centers, global treasury centers. So we cover them between our relationship managers and salespeople exactly how they are organized, and therefore, we have very embedded relationships with these buying centers. So having explained the uniqueness of this, that particular network continues to facilitate a greater share of clients' wallet, be it our existing clients or be it new age clients.

In addition to that, if you look at how the digital economy is evolving today, we are also attracting flows from this new breed of fintechs, which we call aggregators. So what the aggregators do, they aggregate flows from those customer segments we don't directly do business with. So these could be the consumer bank, consumer clients. It could be small businesses around the world. And then they are looking for a platform to distribute it around the world.

And I think what is very important for us to remember is that the globalization is becoming very inclusive. Today, one can produce anything anywhere and distribute it everywhere using these digital platforms. And therefore, that access to a global platform is very, very important. So we feel very confident.

And then, of course, on top of that, we are continuously investing in that innovation, improving the client experience, broadening our product capabilities, operational resilience. So we believe that we are unique, our positioning. We feel good about our positioning, that as the environment evolves as we go into the future, we will be able to maintain that growth despite the -- of course, we will have impacts of the economic headwinds and interest rate volatility. But through the cycle, we believe that our growth rate will be over the GDP growth rates.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: So let's talk about the competitive landscape a little bit. You're in 98 countries with banking licenses, so it's very hard to replicate. The presence that you have had for as long as you have had it at several banks, and it's a small handful, have a similar infrastructure and capability, but there's always change in the competitive landscape, whether it's new entrants into the treasury services business or otherwise. Can we talk a little bit about what you're seeing there in terms of the competitive landscape?

NAVEED SULTAN: Yes. I mean clearly, the -- there is a widespread recognition in the market that this is a very attractive business. So you are seeing both traditional and nontraditional players coming into this particular space. And as far as we are concerned, like I made the point in the earlier discussion, that we have a very unique and differentiated position. Our strategy is informed by 2 things: what the client needs are; and secondly, that we want to be the financial platform for global commerce.

If you look at today, how the world is evolving, 7 of the topmost valuable companies in the world today are platform companies. And we have a unique opportunity because of these assets we have built to make that transition into becoming the financial platform for global commerce. And therefore, we are really making a lot of investments in 4 areas: client experience; connectivity and data; innovation; and safety, soundness and operational resilience. So we believe that our competitive position is strong, and we will continue to gain the market share.

Now if you look at the nontraditional players, the nontraditional players which would, really you think about the fintechs. The portion of the fintech on the institutional side has become more collaborative. On the consumer side, it's more competitive because the fintech on the consumer side think that it's easier to disintermediate the consumer relationships. On the institutional side, there is a recognition that the relationships are so embedded. Therefore, it's very difficult to disintermediate.

And particularly, in our case, because of relationships, global scale, the fintechs find our platform very attractive to come and work with us from an operating standpoint. So therefore, we work very closely with the fintechs as partners as well as its clients. In fact, we have built a practice within our financial institutions group, what we call fintech. So as clients, we want to facilitate them to grow their business around the world.

And as far as the collaboration is concerned, partnerships, we integrate their capabilities into our solutions. They bring new ideas, technology. We have the scale, the trust and client access. So that relationship works exceedingly well. So I think this competitive interest is a confirmation of the opportunity, and we actually find it a very positive motivator to make sure we don't become complacent and we stay ahead of the game.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: So it's interesting when I think about this change in the competitive environment, and you talk about it as a catalyst. One of the things that's so attractive about these businesses is that the market is huge, right? It's huge whether you look at just the U.S. version or the global version, and obviously, you're looking at the global version.

It's massively fragmented, right? There's very little good data available, but your market share is somewhere between, let's call it, 5% and 6%. I think JPMorgan told us on Tuesday that theirs was about 6%, which I'm going to assume you're then close to 6-ish percent as well. But these market shares haven't really moved. The top 3 players are all in the 5%, 6%-ish range, and there's only a top 3 or top 5 players. What are in -- what is, in your view, the driver of incremental market share consolidation? Because in every other business, you should be looking to be at 2x that market share.

NAVEED SULTAN: I think -- yes, absolutely. It's a great question. So like you said, I think the market is very fragmented. And it depends upon what lens you are using, and it's difficult to estimate. Coalition actually puts our market share around 9%, 9% to 10%, considering our revenues last year of $10 billion. So total addressable wallet, you can say, give and take, about $100 billion. That is large corporates, our formally defined target market, but we are not competing in the rest of the market. So it could be a different lens if you say 5%, it's much bigger. Overall...

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: I'm using an overall market.

NAVEED SULTAN: Yes, overall. Yes, exactly. So no, no, it's a very, very, very good question. So what we believe is that if you look at how the consolidation or how the transition has been happening over the years, in the past, whatever the underlying driver of consolidation -- so let's say, post financial and economic crisis, we saw many of our peer group retrenching closer to their home markets geographically or they're exiting relating business lines. The natural flow of that business was our platform, so it got consolidated on our platform.

There is another very important driver, which is not very well understood. Then the clients -- because the trend of efficiency and value creation is secular, that's where the clients are going. So when they look at the value creation either on the top line or becoming more efficient, they start looking at consolidation of some of their activities.

So we are the market leaders in supply chain finance, in addition to the overall market leadership and commercial cards. Now these are fairly recent business lines. So say, up till a few years ago, this particular business was allocated by our clients to disparate providers in different geographies around the world, and that obviously is very inefficient. That's fragmented. You have to deal with so many different providers. When they started looking for the benefits of scale, consistency of experience and one single provider, we were the natural beneficiaries. And so they started consolidating their supply chain business with us. They started consolidating their commercial card business with us.

If you look at the -- amongst other things, if you look at the impact of digitization and globalization, it's going to go towards consolidation. And by and large, they are looking for a global platform. And as you very well know, the industry boundaries -- industries are converging and -- into ecosystems. So therefore, we believe that our strategy of being the financial platform for global commerce is absolutely the right one. And our in-depth relationships across different segments will allow us to continue to gain the market share, either by consolidation; offering them new solutions as we navigate these changes in the marketplace; and thirdly, to your point, which was the right one, that it actually broadens our access to the market beyond that $100 billion.

The example I gave of the aggregators, the flows which aggregators bring are not part of our formal defined market. So once -- when you are a platform, your ability to access much broader market improves quite considerably. So I think net-net, we believe that we are extremely well positioned for growth, and there are multiple sources of growth, both how we engage with the market traditionally as well as how the new flows are being created. And we believe that platform is in a much better position to services.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: And just to clarify here. If we were sitting here 15 or 20 years ago, we would have talked about very high switching costs, right? I believe that given where technology is today, the switching costs are far lower. So while relationships are embedded from a human standpoint, the technology to make that switch from one provider to the next or add another provider to a platform is much easier facilitated today.

NAVEED SULTAN: Again, I think it's a great question because your conventional thinking tend to suggest that the switching cost being high is a good thing, that the inefficiency or how much you got connected with the client and all that. I think the way the world is going, your switching cost is delivered by your -- quality of your client experience.

The technology allows you to switch very quickly.

I mean if you look at different cab services providers or transport services providers, you can switch just by clicking a few icons on your smartphone. But what keeps you with one particular provider is the quality of the experience they give you. And I think that's exactly what our strategy is. So we are making a huge amount of investment into improving the client experience.

So I'll just give you one example. In the traditional lens, which was like the switching cost -- and it's a very pertinent point because it will take about 2, 2.5 months to open an account of a client or onboarded. So if you think about it, it is a very high switching cost. So if client has already a relationship with you would saying, "Well, you're the new client, new bank, it will take me another 2, 2.5 months to open an account." Yes, you find that these guys are not perfect, but the switching cost is very high. I don't want to switch. We have reduced that down to 48 hours. It's all digital. It's live in 34 markets because we believe that you got to keep the client with yourself through delivering economic value. And if you're scalable, you have a great client experience, very easy.

The opposite of very easy connectivity is that you can also very easily leave, right? So if you have those attributes, we believe actually, in our case, the sources of value get very diversified. Because you're attracting all the flows, it's very easy to do business with. Your marginal cost is approaching 0 because it's very scalable. And then you are offering not only your own proprietary solutions, third-party solutions are also coming on to your platform. And therefore, I think our ability to continue to grow, it's basically reflecting all the attributes of a platform business model as we see it in the industry today.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: So if I connect a few dots here, at the beginning of our conversation, we talked about not just growth but consistent pretax margin improvement and the amount of technology investment, it sounds like, you've made in the business to be down to onboarding a client in 48 hours. If I tie these things together, it would indicate to me that you've invested pretty aggressively in the operating infrastructure of the business to reduce the marginal cost, the unit operating cost of transacting. How much is it about reducing -- tie together for me maybe the benefit of reducing the unit operating cost as well as that seems to be what's translating to better customer service, and it's really very tightly married together.

NAVEED SULTAN: Absolutely. You're absolutely right. So like I said, if you are executing that particular strategy and when you're making investments in improving the client experience, reducing the redundancies, friction points, your unit cost is -- marginal unit cost is reducing. And that is an outcome of the fact that you were taking out the redundancies, you are taking out the friction points vis-a-vis the clients. And that, in turn, gives the clients incentive to direct more flows into your platform because it's so easy, it's a great experience. And of course, if your marginal cost is approaching 0 over a period of time, you also have -- and part of that, you can always pass it on to your clients based on -- that's an economic decision you have to make, but you have the flexibility to pass part of that onto your clients.

It's a very interesting dynamic that you improve the unit cost, you take out the friction, you make it a lot easier for clients to do business with you. On the other side, it starts building the scale, and it creates that virtuous cycle of more scale and more volumes, reduce the marginal cost, economic incentives flowing back to the client, more volumes coming through. And then, of course, you're always adding new innovations, you are bringing in technology from new partners.

So I'll give you 2 examples. Recently, HighRadius, which is one of the fintech partners, we've also taken an equity position. They use machine learning and artificial intelligence and natural language processing to solve one of the big pain points in the industry. And that is essentially when the -- a payment comes in, how you reconcile with the receivables side. And that has been one of the big pain points. We launched that within a span of about 3 to 6 months in a partnership.

So the reason I'm highlighting that is that it's not just the scale and the marginal cost, we are also adding more products, more solutions, proprietary or third party. And that is exactly the characteristics of a platform that the interaction of those 4 continues to clear -- create nonlinear growth. So we are in this transition right now, but we are very excited about the prospects of the platform we have.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: And so let's just talk about data on that platform for a minute because data and analytics and artificial intelligence are all taking the -- not just your unit operating cost down but also providing value added to the customer. So let's talk about, for a minute, how it is that you're harnessing the data that's available to you across Citi, for both Citi and for the clients.

NAVEED SULTAN: Yes. A lot has been said about data, and one expression which I find very interesting is that data is the oil of 21st century. And I -- we generally believe that the generation, management and monetization of data in a systematic manner at the institutional level is going to create a very significant differentiation. And our approach is that when these new technologies come in, we don't want to be engaged with these technologies on the periphery of how we do business with it today. We want to fundamentally rethink how we do business so that we can leverage the full outcome of these technologies.

So what we have done is, in data, we are making a lot of investments into the underlying infrastructure of organizing the data so it is accessible and we can drive client insights out of it. In TTS, we have created 4 horizontals, and one of the horizontals is data. What does a horizontal mean? Some of these technologies don't lend themselves to vertical organization because they cut across your different business lines. So this data horizontal cuts across products, geographies and customer segments so that we can build the right infrastructure and the relevant. So our investment is driven by that we are embedding data in all our solutions and products as well as the client journey with us.

So I'll give you 2, 3 examples really to make it real for you. So when we start engaging with the client in terms of developing a solution or helping them solve a pain point, we analyze the data, we model it. We benchmark it based on several variables which the client give us, how they are organized around the world, what is the legal regulatory jurisdictions, foreign exchange, restrictions, where they want long, their liquidity, where they want short liquidity, all the rest of this. So it's actually hundreds of variables. So we put all of those into our model, and then we create the best possible outcome, which can be actually -- and this is interactive on digital front end. And you can sit in front of a client and keep moving until the client thinks, "I think this is the optimum outcome." So that is when you start creating a solution.

When you bring the client onboard, the Know Your Customer compliance requirements as well as opening the account, entitling the products, we look at all our internal data. We go to third-party sources and get the information relating to the company. And then we have -- ask the client minimal questions in terms of additional information so that we don't cause inconvenience. And that is one of the drivers why we have reduced it down to 48 hours. Once the client is onboard, start doing business, we use biometrics, bio-matrices. We use artificial intelligence, obviously exploiting the data to fraud prevention, giving them the best possible execution, reconciliation as well as financing utilization and predicting the liquidity flow.

And fourthly, once they are in a BAU environment with us, doing business, our exploitation of data, usage of data, we keep proactively giving them suggestions that this particular geography has made these changes in the regulation, your company has done this particular acquisition or even if you're staying with your current structure, we believe that if you organize this particular way, you have a better outcome for your liquidity and for your assets. And particularly these days, as we know, the global supply chains are shifting for different reasons. So the clients are looking at their operational footprint again. They are looking at how the new supply chains are going to look like. So our knowledge of the market, deep understanding of the local rules and regulations, coupled with the understanding of the client, we proactively give them recommendation based on data.

So we -- so as you can see, we are embedding data in a very thoughtful manner in the client journey with us in every step. And we believe that is the right way to do it as opposed to just have a peripheral approach to data, which superimposes on your current operating environment, which may or may not be compatible. And by the way, that is true for other technologies as well.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: That seems to me as one more element of kind of completing and accelerating the journey around the virtuous cycle in this business.

NAVEED SULTAN: Yes, absolutely.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: Okay. So I'm at 0 on the clock. If I have you back in 3 years, let's see another 35% growth. I know that's a little bit difficult to do, but we do look forward to watching your growth outpace GDP growth.

NAVEED SULTAN: No, no, absolutely. And I think I can't put a number out there, but we are very, very excited about the prospect of this. And the way to look at this business is in the context of financial platform for global commerce. The world is increasingly becoming global despite the geopolitics, trade tensions and tariffs. And I think some of these global changes and structural shifts get -- go unnoticed because of these headlines. But fundamentally, the global supply chains are becoming more knowledge-intensive, more services-intensive.

Only 18% of the global trade today is driven by cost arbitrage, and there are many other factors at play. So the point I'm making is that every client of ours, because of our global experience and deep relationships in those markets, wants to have our advice and insights how they rethink and navigate in this changing world. And that's we believe is what offers us an exciting opportunity as we move forward here.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: Thank you.

NAVEED SULTAN: Thank you, Susan. It's always a pleasure to be here.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: Thank you. Citi will be available for a breakout session in -- I believe it's the Plaza 1 room, to the right.

NAVEED SULTAN: Thank you so much.

SUSAN ROTH KATZKE: Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5XBK-2GX1-JC8G-817T-00000-00Citing Big Tech Data Dominance, FTC's Chopra Warns of Regulatory Capture2019-10-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:36ZLexisNexisTOP NEWSCiting Big Tech Data Dominance, FTC's Chopra Warns of Regulatory Capture

FTC Commissioner Rohit Chopra warned Congress about the threat of regulatory capture Friday, contending data-rich tech companies wield excessive power. "All too often, the government is too captured by those incumbents who use their power to dictate their preferred policies," he told the House Antitrust Subcommittee.

Chairman David Cicilline, D-R.I., told reporters the Democratic commissioner's concerns are "serious, and I share them." The worry is tech companies have "disproportionate influence over the regulatory process," he said. The House Judiciary Committee bipartisan investigation involves major tech companies, and FTC enforcement and other practices, he said. "I wouldn't say [the FTC is] under investigation. It's not a prosecution, but ... they're part of our review in this comprehensive investigation." Cicilline said the committee is expecting more material later after collecting tens of thousands of documents in initial responses from Alphabet, Amazon, Apple and Facebook last Monday.

Chopra suggests a corporate royalty controls the economy, but the reality is a regulatory royalty controls politics, said American Enterprise Institute Visiting Scholar Roslyn Layton. After 18 months under EU's general data protection regulation, the largest tech platforms gained market share in the EU, while fledgling rivals have lost ground, she said, noting that online trust is at its lowest since 2006.

The FTC could use more resources and tools, Chopra said, but the biggest thing is to energetically examine and use existing tools. Reconsider its antitrust presumptions and maybe shift the burden onto tech companies to prove their acquisitions aren't harmful, he recommended. Chopra again aired frustration about the agency's $5 billion privacy settlement with Facebook, criticizing that CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg weren't deposed. Deterrence isn't adequate without executive accountability, he said.

In the past decade, five of the largest tech platforms have acquired more than 400 companies without any real challenge from antitrust enforcers, said Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler, D-N.Y. Subcommittee ranking member Jim Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., warned against punishing success. Antitrust laws exist to promote success, he said. He blamed the GDPR and the California Consumer Privacy Act for "collateral damage."

Lawmakers and witnesses agreed privacy and competition are increasingly intersecting. "The relationship between competition and privacy is not either/or," Cicilline said. They're related "concepts that must be at the forefront as we consider proposals to restore the internet to its full promise." Policymakers can't silo privacy from competition, testified Harvard economist Jason Furman. Privacy is at the core of the economics of digital markets, and it shapes competition, said Imperial College Business School economist Tommaso Valletti. He also blamed large tech companies for not providing the data needed to properly assess competition concerns.

Competition for markets, like the social media market Facebook dominates, will be difficult absent significant policy changes, said Furman. Tech acquisitions are repeatedly approved without scrutiny, he said. Citing a tech sector antitrust immunity, Valletti suggested lowering thresholds for what triggers deal review. Chopra often wonders what the world would look like if Google hadn't bought YouTube, for instance, and small competitors could grow on their own.

Hidden privacy policy terms are a "price hike" that needs to be considered when looking at competition, Chopra said. He argued Facebook unseated MySpace partially through its claims about privacy and control. Facebook says users would "be able to control who sees your information," he recalled. "We should want firms to compete on terms of privacy." Chopra declined to answer reporter questions after the hearing.

urn:contentItem:5WC4-R1K1-DYRJ-035C-00000-00Citing Market Power, GOP State AGs Suggest Big Tech Breakup Is Needed2019-06-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:35ZLexisNexisTOP NEWSCiting Market Power, GOP State AGs Suggest Big Tech Breakup Is Needed

Big tech companies like Google might need to be broken up because Silicon Valley market power is threatening democracy, three Republican state attorneys general told the FTC Wednesday. During a competition policy hearing, Nebraska AG Doug Peterson (R) urged state enforcers to be fast, thorough and thoughtful in probing the industry: "Once we gather the information necessary, we have to consider whether or not to break things."

"Structural change driven by the government may well be necessary," said Tennessee AG Herbert Slatery (R). "Working around the edges of regulation is probably not going to help. Fines are an appropriate remedy, but they're essentially the cost of business that can easily be passed onto consumers." Internet Association didn't comment.

Through its advertising tech monopoly, Google picks winners and losers, said Louisiana AG Jeff Landry (R): "Continuing down this road will kill online publishing, or Google will control who stays and who goes. How's that for fulfilling the promise of the internet as an open place?" He warned corporate power can become stronger than government and, in turn, democracy. Google can tell advertisers everything they need to know about their target audiences, and it's "wholly" unregulated, Landry said.

Peterson cited Columbia Law School professor Tim Wu's claim concentration of private power is a threat to constitutional design, and antitrust law provides the "final check" on private power. He suggested Google's past buy of DoubleClick was harmful and called false the arguments the market would even itself out. Antitrust law needs to protect the health of the free market, Peterson said, noting the consumer welfare standard can adapt to the tech industry. He said the scope and power of big tech's data is so far-reaching that it's imperative for AGs, DOJ and the FTC to take this "very seriously." Silicon Valley's shift from mobile technology to artificial intelligence means the U.S. needs to be that much more aware, he said.

These "data barons" are able to build "super profiles" of consumers, using location data, purchase data, photos, friends, likes and an endless amount of other information, Peterson said. The question becomes does industry or the consumer own the data, Slatery said. Tennessee believes consumers own the data, and if industry wants to own it, it must secure consent in a transparent manner, Slatery said: "Not a person in this room knows how their data is used, much less the value it holds in the hands of these tech companies." Peterson argued the so-called "free" services aren't entirely free because consumers pay for broadband and mobile use.

There's also a need for transparency on content moderation, said South Dakota AG Jason Ravnsborg (R) on a separate panel. Every organization needs to explain the "rules," he said. If companies "make a mistake or it's part of the algorithm, what are they going to do to change it or make an improvement? Good communication is also essential." The office for Texas AG Ken Paxton (R) encourages self-regulation, Assistant Attorney General Jeff Mateer said: Lacking self-regulation, "I think states, the federal government, us as enforcers, are going to have to seek those type of results."
