urn:contentItem:5VFX-R7W1-F06X-W3TY-00000-00Citi plans machine takeover of call centers; Shareholders bail on two foreign banks2019-02-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:35ZLexisNexisCiti plans machine takeover of call centers; Shareholders bail on two foreign banksGeorge Yacik

Receiving Wide Coverage ...

Earnings missHSBC reported full-year 2018 earnings of $12.6 billion, more than $1 billion less than analysts expected, as fourth quarter profits came in less than forecast. "The bank said customers held off on business when markets turned volatile last year, hitting revenue in its global markets business and retail banking and wealth management units," the Wall Street Journal says.Wall Street Journal,Financial Times

Big fishLittle known Norinchukin Bank, "a 95-year-old bank that holds around $600 billion in deposits from Japan's agricultural and fishing collectives has amassed a significant share of the estimated $700 billion global market for collateralized loan obligations, or CLOs - complex investment vehicles that buy more than half of U.S. loans to junk-rated companies." the Journal reports. "That makes Norinchukin just about as important to a U.S. retailer as it is to a Japanese farmer. The privately held bank's $62 billion CLO portfolio is larger than those of either of the two biggest U.S. bank buyers, Wells Fargo and JPMorgan Chase. And its influence is growing: Norinchukin added about $10 billion to its holdings in the last three months of 2018, nearly a third of all U.S. and European CLO issuance over that period."Wall Street Journal,Financial Times

Financial Times

In jeopardyCitigroup CEO Michael Corbat said "tens of thousands" of people in the bank's call centerscould be replaced by machinesthat can both "radically change or improve" customers' experience and reduce costs. His comments "are the most explicit the company has been on how the $8 billion a year Citi spends on technology could transform its vast consumer bank, which serves 100 million customers across 19 markets," the paper says.

Selling offTwo of Europe's biggest banks have lost some critical investor support. U.S. hedge fund Tiger Global, which "had been among the staunchest defenders of chief executive Jes Staley's plan to improve the bank's languishing share price by reviving its investment bank," has sold its entire stake in Barclays. "Tiger's exit comes at a difficult juncture for Barclays, which is trying to prevent Edward Bramson, the activist investor, from forcing his way on to the board andengineering a shift in strategythat would involve shrinking the investment bank."

Separately, HNA, the big Chinese insurance company and Deutsche Bank's largest shareholder, has reduced its stake in the bank "by nearly a fifth to 6.3%. The move is the latest in a recentseries of retreatsmade by the financially stretched Chinese group."

No shorts allowedGermany's financial regulator has barred investors from shorting the stock of digital payments company Wirecard, "marking the first time it has used such powers to restrict trading in a single stock," the paper says. BaFin last used the measure during the 2008 financial crisis to protect the stocks of 11 banks. The regulator cited Wirecard's "importance for the economy" and the "serious threat to market confidence" following a recent nosedive in its stock price after the paper "revealed the existence of an internal investigation intoalleged accounting irregularitiesinvolving several of the group's subsidiaries in Asia."

Eye on AmericaBritish fintech GoCardless has raised $75 million "from some of the biggest technology investors" as it prepares to launch in the U.S. this year. The company "allows its more than 30,000 corporate clients to collect recurring payments online using bank account details rather than debit and credit card numbers. The company processesabout $10 billion of paymentsglobally every year."

Not kid stuffSo-called sandboxes for financial technology experimentation create an image "of small boys clad in tiny hoodies using little pails. In fact, these sandboxes are battlefields on which the big tech companies are taking great risks with our financial future," argues Karen Petrou, managing partner of Federal Financial Analytics, in an op-ed. "It's troubling enough that Facebook, Google and the like know where we live, who our friends are, and what we think. Consumers offered a savings account by a tech company are unlikely to understand that its higher-returnproducts come with a hidden catch: no safety net or upfront capital to cover claims for redress. Those who trust fintech providers are taking risks virtually no one can predict. With so much at stake, we cannot wait to find out if sandboxes allow cage fighting."

New York Times

Branching outAs American banks "shift employees and hundreds of billions of dollars' worth of assets from London to new subsidiaries" across the European Union, "one thing is clear about the legacy of Brexit: Financial services will be spread across Europe, withno one city again dominatingthe financial arena as London has."

Washington Post

Misconduct allegedThe Federal Housing Finance Agency's inspector general said former Director Mel Watt attempted to "coerce or induce" arelationship with a female employeewho sought a promotion and accused him of two counts of misconduct. The IG's report, which was completed last November, was obtained by the paper through a Freedom of Information Act request. "We find that there are no circumstances under which it would be appropriate for the head of FHFA to induce a subordinate female employee to meet with him alone, in his apartment, for a conversation in which he professes his attraction for that employee and holds out opportunities for the employee to serve in specific executive positions over which he exercises total control," the report says. Watt, who retired at the end of his term last month, has denied he did anything wrong.

Quotable

"When you think of data, AI artificial intelligence, raw digitization of changing processes, we still have tens of thousands of people in call centers, and we know when we can digitize those processes we not onlyradically change or improve the customer experience, it costs less to provide.

Sep 11, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ;; Hello.It's been 19 years since 9/11, but the pain is still very real for many of us. Nearly two decades later, the anniversary still holds significant weight, particularly for Wall Street, as so many financial firms had offices in the World Trade Center.Since the attacks, there have been plenty of fantastic pieces written uncovering countless acts of heroism. However, if you decide to read one piece today, I encourage you to check out this story from The New Yorker[1] originally published in February 2002. It's a profile of Rick Rescorla, who was a VP in charge of security at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and credited for saving thousands of lives thanks to evacuation plans he put in place prior to the attacks.The entire story is worth a read[2], but the final paragraph, a quote from Rescorla's best friend, is one that has always stuck with me, and is representative of many who lost their lives that day."I've tried to tell Susan this, in a way, but she's not ready yet for the truth. In the next weeks or months, I'll get her down here, and we'll take a walk along the ocean, and I'll explain these things.

You see, for Rick Rescorla, this was a natural death. People like Rick, they don't die old men. They aren't destined for that and it isn't right for them to do so. It just isn't right, by God, for them to become feeble, old, and helpless sons of bitches. There are certain men born in this world, and they're supposed to die setting an example for the rest of the weak bastards we're surrounded with."If you're not yet a subscriber, you can sign up here to get your daily dose of the stories dominating banking, business, and big deals.[3]You can also register here for Business Insider's Master Your Money Live Digital Bootcamp series, presented by Fidelity. Check out the virtual event "How to Be a Smarter Investor Now" on September 15 at 12 p.m.[4]Like the newsletter? Hate the newsletter? Feel free to drop me a line at ddefrancesco@businessinsider.com [5] or on Twitter @DanDeFrancesco[6]. urn:contentItem:60MR-HHT1-F19Y-C087-00000-00Citi sues Revlon lender; EC approves Nets-Mastercard deal; Westpac posts results2020-08-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:35ZLexisNexisExtraCiti sues Revlon lender; EC approves Nets-Mastercard deal; Westpac posts resultsMary Christine Joy

S&P Global Market Intelligence's daily overview of essential financial news globally.

Note to readers: S&P Global Market Intelligence is pleased to introduce The Daily Dose: Global Financials, featuring the biggest stories in the banking and financial services industry across the world.

TOP NEWS

* Citigroup Inc. filed a lawsuit against Revlon Inc. lender Brigade Capital Management LP to recover $175 million the bank mistakenly transferred to the hedge fund, the Financial Times reported. Citi was supposed to send only $1.5 million in accrued interest on a term loan Brigade Capital held but made the payment as part of the erroneous $900 million transfer made to creditors of the troubled cosmetics company. Additionally, sources for Bloomberg News said the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve are reviewing Citi's mistaken payment to Revlon lenders.

* The European Commission approved U.S.-based Mastercard Inc.'s proposed acquisition of Danish payments firm Nets A/S' account-to-account payment business, saying both companies offered remedies to address competition concerns it previously raised. The two companies offered to transfer a global license to distribute, supply, sell, develop, modify, upgrade or use Nets' Realtime 24/7 technology to a suitable purchaser.

* Westpac Banking Corp. decided not to distribute an interim dividend for the fiscal first half ended March 31 after reporting an increase in cash earnings for the fiscal third quarter ended June 30 from the preceding six-month period. The Australian bank's cash earnings, excluding items such as provisions for refunds and other costs, totaled A$1.32 billion for the three months ended June 30. The lender canceled the interim dividend due to economic uncertainties and its objective to retain a strong balance sheet.

As 'big tech' dominates cloud use for banks, regulators may need to get tougher

Banks rely heavily on a small number of "big tech" players for cloud infrastructure. Industry insiders say a concentration of power in the hands of just a few providers creates risks for the financial sector.

Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan top gainers in strong Q2 i-bank trading

The leading global investment banks had another strong trading quarter, with fixed income, currencies and commodities driving most of the revenue gains, S&P Global Market Intelligence data shows. U.S. banks continued to outperform European peers.

U.S. & CANADA

* After leaving the topic alone for nearly two decades, the National Association of Insurance Commissioners is restarting its work on examining the role that race plays in insurance affordability and availability. During a special session held as part of the NAIC's virtual summer national meeting, consumer advocates and regulators called for recognition of systemic racism and inherent bias in the insurance industry and offered thoughts on how to tackle the issue.

* Thurmont, Md.-based MBFT FCU is seeking to merge into Frederick, Md.-based Nymeo FCU, the Credit Union Journal reported. Nymeo FCU has more than $314 million in assets, while MBFT FCU has $521,000 in assets, according to the report.

Click here for more of the day's essential bank and financial services news in the U.S. and Canada, and here for more of the day's global insurance news.

LATIN AMERICA

* Brazil's Banco do Estado do Rio Grande do Sul SA announced it plans to carry out a voluntary termination program for its employees, without providing any more details.

* Brazil-based StoneCo Ltd. said it closed an offering of an aggregate 31,481,250 class A common shares Aug. 17, with gross proceeds of about $1.50 billion. The underwriters exercised in full their option to purchase an additional 4,106,250 shares.

Click here for more of the day's essential financial news in Latin America.

EUROPE

* Intesa Sanpaolo SpA is likely to be involved in a potential bid for Borsa Italiana SpA by Netherlands-based pan-European exchange Euronext NV and Italy's Cassa depositi e prestiti SpA, insiders told Bloomberg News. The Italian cabinet is expected to meet this week to review its strategy regarding Borsa Italiana, the report noted, citing La Stampa.

* Danish lender Jyske Bank A/S' second-quarter net profit distributed to shareholders rose year over year to 820 million kroner from 459 million kroner, with loan impairment charges narrowing quarter over quarter to 8 million kroner from 1.00 billion kroner amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The bank expects a full-year 2020 net profit in the range of 1 billion kroner to 1.5 billion kroner.

Click here for more of the day's essential financial news in Europe.

MIDDLE EAST & AFRICA

* Mizrahi Tefahot Bank Ltd.'s second-quarter net profit attributable to shareholders stood at 360 million Israeli shekels, down from 576 million shekels a year ago, as expenses related to credit losses surged due to the coronavirus crisis. Expenses concerning credit losses totaled 270 million shekels in the second quarter, compared to the year-ago 99 million shekels.

* Fitch Ratings downgraded Oman's long-term foreign- and local-currency issuer default ratings to BB- from BB, with a negative outlook, citing the combined impact of low oil prices and the COVID-19 pandemic on the country's fiscal and external metrics.

Click here for more of the day's essential financial news in the Middle East and Africa.

ASIA PACIFIC

* Malaysia's Ministry of Finance launched the issuance of Sukuk Prihatin, the country's first digital sukuk, with a target amount of 500 million ringgit. The issuance is in response to requests by multiple parties to contribute towards the country's recovery efforts.

* The risk assets held by Japan's three megabanks increased by ¥4 trillion to ¥243 trillion in the three months to June, Tokyo's The Nikkei reported. Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's risk assets increased by ¥250 billion to ¥115 trillion, while Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group and Mizuho Financial Group reported increases in risk assets of ¥890 billion to ¥62 trillion and of ¥3 trillion to ¥65 trillion, respectively.

Click here for more of the day's essential financial news in Asia Pacific.

MARKETS

Read more about today's financial markets in Global Markets Today, a daily feature setting out the factors driving stocks, bonds and currencies around the world ahead of the New York open.

urn:contentItem:5VS1-YM31-F0JP-W219-00000-00CITIZEN OR CONSUMER?2019-03-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:35ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 44CITIZEN OR CONSUMER?JAMIE SEIDEL

The power artificial intelligence has over us has put the future of government in the balance, writes JAMIE SEIDEL WE'RE about to head into a federal election. But government itself is in a fight for its life - and doesn't even know it.

The pillars of society - law, justice and enforcement - are being snatched from the hands of our elected leaders. Algorithmic rules set by international corporations have exploded into the limelight with the Christchurch massacre. But it goes far beyond social media.

AI (Artificial Intelligence) judges your resumes, credit history and performance metrics. AI chooses what you read and watch. AI punishes your credit ratings.

But many of the rules that are now being imposed by international corporate algorithms have little or no government oversight.

Now futurists are warning civilisation itself is at a crossroads: Will we be citizens - or consumers?

Australian political philosopher and futurist Dr Tim Dunlop, who recently authored the book The Future of Everything, warns our digital destiny is ominous: "The technologies of control are increasingly being deployed in ever more draconian ways, from the workplace to the ballot box." And society is barely even aware of the immense impact of ungoverned algorithms on our daily lives.

We live with technology. We live through technology.

That means we're controlled by how that technology works.

Take the example of a self-driving car: Can you tell it to drive faster than the speed limit? Will it allow you to park on a yellow line? Will it deliver you to the storefront of a competitor?

Its actions are limited to the rules coded into it. But who controls the coders? Employers? Governments? International treaties? Market forces?

Those rules are not necessarily guided by legislators, written in public, consistently applied - or even designed with the public interest in mind. But they are a new level of governance we've never had to live with before.

The implications for all of us are enormous.

Algorithms are reading your curriculum vitae, judging whether to put it on the top of the pile or at the bottom. But is the code it uses sexist? Racist? Ageist?

Algorithms assess your credit history, income level and expenditure habits to judge if you're eligible for a loan. Algorithms already decide whether or not to pick you up for a ride.

Software engineers have become social engineers.

But determining who gets what is supposed to be the domain of politics. Should algorithms be judges, juries and executioners? Or should they be governed?

Are multinational corporations really up to the responsibility of algorithmic world governance?

"No," says Dr Dunlop. "They are run by self-serving (mainly) men who don't have moral ballast to run a chook raffle, let alone a country or the world. Their own companies are already modelling draconian behaviours in regard to their workers: Why would it be any different from any other sort of governance they are involved in?" He offers a drastic answer: "We need not just to break up big tech companies as (US senator) Elizabeth Warren wants to do. We need to bring them into public ownership. They need to be subject to democratic, not market, control." It's taken millennia to evolve the systems of government and justice we have today.

We've been living with corporate algorithms for little more than a decade. Things are changing. Fast.

And futurists such as Jamie Susskind, barrister, past Fellow of Harvard University's Berkman Centre for internet and Society, and author of Future Politics, warn we'll have to reinvent government.

"Those who control the most powerful technologies will increasingly control the rest of us. And certainly, one way that they might be able to do that is through gathering data about us and using that data to influence or manipulate us," he says.

The art of administration is immensely difficult. Western civilisation tried everything from tribal chiefs and kings through to communism and democracy.

But, we still haven't got it right.

"It's impossible, but we have no choice," Dr Dunlop says. "For all that, we have learned some things. And mainly what we've learned is that massive inequality damages democracy.

"So we need systems and institutions that equalise wealth and therefore power. Revolution and the like arise when elites forget that they need to share." According to Dr Dunlop, we've forgotten the struggles of history that have given us the free and democratic lives we have.

"It took blood and determination from the vulnerable," he says. "No elite ever gave up power willingly. All they will ever do is share to preserve their own privilege. As Thomas Jefferson said, 'The tree of liberty must be refreshed from time to time with the blood of patriots and tyrants. It is its natural manure'." The recent Cambridge Analytica scandal revealed it had been able to gather information from 5000 different data points on 200 million individual US citizens. This enabled them to identify which voters would be most susceptible to different political messages.

Now, the world is increasingly awash with strongmen.

Authoritarianism is regaining its appeal.

What if a data-crunching firm such as Cambridge Analytica was working for Nazi Germany or Fascist Italy? What if these dictators had got their hands on this trove of information about the habits of each and every one of us?

Susskind says our future isn't yet set. But it may soon be.

"It is fluid, who the power might reside with in the future," he says, "although I regret that it increasingly doesn't look like - if things continue as they are - it will reside in the hands of us, the citizens." And it's 50-50 whether our new overlords will be governments or corporations. He says there must be a seismic shift in our awareness: Governments and voters must value data from a citizen's perspective, not that of a customer.

Dr Dunlop says we must refuse to allow market forces to control our politics: "Voting and buying are different. In a market, the winner takes all. In a democracy, even the loser must be protected. Democracy is about protecting the rights of the minority. It is not winner-takes-all.

"Which is why I want them (big data corporations) - the really big ones - nationalised. We are not a resource to be mined; we are citizens with rights." Information is power. And we have little idea how much information about our daily lives we are giving up every time we download a new app, browse web pages or enter search terms.

To big business, Dr Dunlop says that data is now more valuable than oil. And it's mined directly from you.

"Every major business is now, or soon will be, a data organisation," he says. "Data is their primary resource. Woolworths, for example, is a huge real-time experiment in data management drawn from their cash registers, emails, loyalty cards and the like. This governs the emails they send out. Where they place stock in their store. What stock they buy. Their supply chains. We are surveilled in basically every transaction we undertake, online or off." And that data can be used for a great deal more than marketing. It can be used to guide what we know. This determines what we believe. And that affects government at every level.

Dr Dunlop warns we must seize back control of data drawn from our personal lives.

He argues companies must pay for the right to record and process our activities. But is this even possible?

"Everything is hard to do," Dr Dunlop says. "The horse has already bolted. We nonetheless have to rein it in. There are alternatives, and the first step towards achieving them is to acknowledge their existence. The next step is not letting anyone tell you something can't be done." Digital technology is muscling in on political functions.

AI surveils the function of free speech, the heart of democracy. AI guides and compels us to do things we wouldn't otherwise do. AI assumes the roles of justice - such as the distribution of services, the allocation of jobs and mortgages and insuranceâ€¦.

"Now that tech is colonising the world of the political, is it acceptable for that technology to be developed and judged solely by reference to market principles?" asks Susskind. "My answer is no. I think, rather than seeing the marketisation of politics, we will have to see the politicisation of markets - where we impose political norms and standards on big tech firms." Big Data firms have assumed, whether they know it or not and even whether they like it or not what have traditionally been political powers. Dr Dunlop says this is why we must come to grips with the value of privacy.

"We haven't forgotten. It's just that to live in the world, you have to use these technologies. You can't - or it is very difficult to - live without a credit card or an email address. We've probably been lulled a bit, but the bottom line is that we need to make sure these industries are regulated so our rights, like privacy, are guaranteed."But his vision of the future is stark: "There is a theory that we only get change in the wake of a massive disaster, either a natural disaster like a plague or man-made one like a war. It's up to us to achieve change without that."

urn:contentItem:5SG6-PFK1-DXH2-633B-00000-00Citizens Financial Group Inc at Sanford C Bernstein Strategic Decisions Conference - Final2018-05-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:36ZLexisNexis053118a11494871.771Citizens Financial Group Inc at Sanford C Bernstein Strategic Decisions Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Bruce W. Van Saun

Citizens Financial Group, Inc. - Chairman, President & CEO

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Okay. Good afternoon, everybody. Thank you for sticking around. We -- pleased to have with us Bruce Van Saun, CEO of Citizens Financial. And I think you know the drill by now. What we'll do is do 20 to 30 minutes of fireside chat-style Q&A. You have the cards on your seats or next to you. As questions come up, please fill them out, and I'll start mixing them in at the 20- to 30-minute point at some point. So Bruce, thank you for being here once again.

Questions and Answers

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: A year ago when we sat here, some of the postelection optimism had worn off the bank sector, but since then, we've seen some real positive developments in terms of rates, tax reform, deregulation. Perhaps you could give us your view on the outlook for the banking sector in the near to medium term?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN, CHAIRMAN, PRESIDENT & CEO, CITIZENS FINANCIAL GROUP, INC.: Well, I actually am quite bullish on the outlook for the banking sector. We have an administration that's focused on a growth agenda and that's favorable for banking performance. So I think you should see that transmitted through to higher loan demand as this year goes on. You also see, I think, interest rates continue on their upward path, which is good for asset-sensitive banks and less regulation also, I think, frees up resources to focus on doing more for customers and doing more for the real economy. So there's a number of reasons that I think the outlook continues to be sanguine. I think borrowers are in good shape, so interest rates rise has been moderate, and we don't see signs of stress from a credit standpoint. And there is a lot of focus now on transformational business models to become more digital and to figure out how to use data and to become more personal in your interactions with your customers. And so it's a very interesting time, but I think there's a bit of a tailwind.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And then specifically in terms of Citizens, you appear, certainly, more leveraged than most regional banks to all of the good things that have happened and continue to happen in terms of rates sensitivity, tax reform, excess capital. As we move forward past these near-term positives, what are your key priorities over the next few years?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Well, I think, ultimately, we want to get to a top-performing bank status, where we're highly respected and we run a great consumer bank and we run a great commercial bank. I think the things that should differentiate us would be how we interact with customers, our real focus on helping customers reach their potential, becoming that trusted adviser to individuals on life's journey or companies as they try to grow their businesses. So we got to get that right, if you're going to create long-term franchise value. I think we'll be at this mindset of continuous improvement, like we like to refer to it. So we'll continue to operate the bank with real financial and operating discipline. And I think we've demonstrated that we can do that, and you should expect that to continue. And then the other thing is, we really want to build out excellence in our capabilities because banking is a crowded landscape, and so the places that you're playing, you've got to have top-quality people and top-quality offerings. And so that's part of the build process that we're going through, and I've been quite pleased, since we've separated from RBS, at our ability to really attract top talent into the company.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Right. You mentioned loan growth. Loan growth, C&I loan growth, specifically, for the industry was disappointing last year. And you had some slowing as well, but 1Q looks solid. And the industry trends, and we -- I'm sure you view that, I think we see an acceleration over the balance of the year. What are you hearing from your commercial borrowers? And what do you expect in terms of C&I growth going forward?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Yes. So I think we're still looking for a positive loan growth scenario for this year. We'll see -- I think, right now we are seeing C&I pickup quite dramatically relative to kind of the second half performance of last year. So we had decent level of spot loan growth in Q1. We entered Q2 with very strong pipelines, and we're pulling those pipelines through and the pipelines are refilling. So kind of what I expected to see in response to tax reform and some of the pro-growth policies is starting to gain some traction. So we think that's quite positive. On the Consumer side, we've had more of a niche strategy, where we go into pockets like education refinance loans or some of our installment merchant financing, and I think we've been able to get a decent and consistent level of growth, while also bringing down some areas where we may have a bit of overexposure such as auto and kind of play a balance sheet optimization game in terms of the mix of assets and where we're playing. So we're still able to achieve that growth, notwithstanding we are reducing some portfolios and growing others, but I like the way that the outlook is shaping up for Consumer as well as for Commercial.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And in terms of commercial real estate, which has been an area of relative strength, given that you had low concentration coming out of the IPO, how much runway for growth do you see there?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: I think that market is still behaving quite well. So I think there is a proper amount of discipline on the part of investors/borrowers, and also the banks. And so I think the banks are staying close to another A list clients that they have confidence are good operators and are doing strong projects. And -- but stuff is still getting done. There are still needs in the kind of general geographies that we serve for more of certain types of assets, whether it's multifamily or office or distribution space. And so we're continuing to see some opportunities, and I think we're being properly disciplined about that, but there's still some runway there, and so I think we'll still continue to grow. I'm not sure we'll make it all the way back to being equal weight, but the fact that we start with an underweight position, given what occurred with RBS being overweight and then forcing us to downsize our portfolio, I think we're continuing to regain some market share.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And then back on the Consumer side, you mentioned student and auto and those are 2 areas that I think people, at least investors that I speak with, tend to recoil, and there is some genuine fear about exposures there. What gives you confidence in your...

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: I really don't have -- that's kind of the last of my worry list for us. Because I think where we've chosen to play in terms of risk appetite is really at the high end of the spectrum. So I think our auto portfolio is mostly super prime and high prime, and the same thing with the student loans that we have. And we're probably 2/3 at refi versus in-school lending, and that tends to be even higher credit quality as well. So I think we have good discipline in those 2 spaces and there may be some storm clouds building farther down the credit spectrum, but we are not playing in those parts of the spectrum.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Shifting to the other side of the balance sheet, there's a -- seems to be a hyperfocus with investors now on deposit competition, deposit betas, which have been very low thus far, but we're starting to see some healthy offers. What's your view on deposit competition as we move forward?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Yes, I think that you're seeing the deposit competition in the places that you would expect to see it. And so -- and the betas being higher in the areas where you would expect to see them being higher. So I think, again, the corporates are seeing their loans replaced, and they are generally sophisticated and they have treasurers or CFOs who are saying, "Okay, if you're going to charge me more on my loans, I want more on my cash." And so you're seeing that ramp at a decent clip now. I think wealth customers as well who -- 5% or 10% of their invested portfolio that's sitting in cash, that's -- that can be real money to make sure you're getting a little better return and squeezing out more on that cash. So the areas that you would expect to see the betas starting to click up, I think we're seeing, but I think it's what we expected to see, the whole industry expected to see. And I think the more mass balances the consumer balances where there is smaller balances, where it doesn't make as much difference if somebody's got $800 in their savings account, they're not clamoring to see the rate pass through there because it doesn't amount to all that much money at the end of the day. And so the law of those numbers is a big part of your deposit base and that's, I think, helped to keep the overall betas at a manageable level up till now.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Some of the perceived curve busters on the deposit side of the direct-to-consumer banks that we've -- that we see with some of the healthier offers. You recently announced a new direct-to-consumer platform, Citizens Access. Could you tell us about your strategy there? And where you see that going over the next few years?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Yes. I think the overall direct banks, online banks, are targeting a snipe segment of the market that is more rate sensitive and maybe a little more sophisticated and prepared to go online and shop for a better rate. And I think the customer experience there plays into who they get comfortable with, where they want to go shopping, where they want to transact. I think what we've -- as we've continued to digitize the company and get stronger in our digital offerings and really enhance our data analytics and data capabilities, it's just a natural next step to put a direct bank out there, and we have, already, a national consumer lending footprint. We might as well go nationally with an offering around the savings side and the deposit side. So makes a lot of sense to us, and I think it's complementary to what we offer to our customers through the branches and other channels.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: So on the subject of competition, there's been some controversy about how much of the benefit from tax reform that the banks will hold on to versus what will be competed away. What's your view on that?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: I think it's likely that the status quo will hold for some time period. And so I think, generally, banks have become much more sophisticated and looking at rate of return calculations on individual customers or on companies. And so credit oftentimes is already thin -- thinly priced and the way it gets to the total return is looking at the total sale -- the total wallet and bringing in some of those fees and it's in addition to that. So I think there is a bit of price competition in the commercial space today. I'm not sure it's linked to the tax reform. I think it's probably more that as loan growth and people compete more to try to get -- keep their share. And so I think it will be interesting to see in the second half of the year, as loan demand picks back up, do you start to see the competition lifting a little bit because the rising tide lifts all boats and maybe that eases off a bit. I would think that would be the case. So I don't think you're seeing an immediate transmittal of well, let's get really sharp on our loan spreads because now we have a boost to our ROE. I don't really think that's happening. I don't think that will happen for some time. And banks are disciplined on the deposit side too, they could pass it through on the deposits. And I think you're seeing that discipline hold that banks are very motivated to continue to improve their returns.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Maybe shifting gears to some of your revenue and expense initiatives. Your top 1 through 4 initiatives have been aimed at driving revenue growth and expense efficiencies. Can you update us on your most recent progress?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Yes. So I think this is one capability that probably is unique amongst our peer groups, is the ability to have that discipline and that mindset of continuous improvement that we're constantly looking for ways to run the bank better and we try to collect all the ideas we can come up with or that we can get from outside folks who say you should think about this and we're doing this at another bank. And so we put those into a program every year and the size of these things is quite impactful. So the top 1 was $200 million when I first arrived, and we've had a cadence of about $100 million to $125 million with 2, 3 and 4, and we're on track to deliver top 4 in that same range. We did hint that stay tuned for July, which is when we typically announce the next TOP program, that there might be a TOP 5 coming. But I think there is still opportunities to run the bank better, more efficiently, to deepen relationships with customers and drive more revenues. We've tried to keep the mix of those programs at least 50% on the expense side because you all as investors kind of say expense saves, we can take to the bank. We're not always sure about whether the revenue materializes, but we have a way of actually tracking this to make sure that if we say we're going to deliver this, that we monitor and measure have we actually delivered it. So anyway -- but I think that balance has worked out well and served us well.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: In terms of specific initiatives, consumer fee growth has been a target, specifically, mortgage and wealth management. You have some news today in the mortgage side. Maybe you could -- for those who haven't seen it, maybe you could sort of...

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Sure. So we had a lot of work to do, when I arrived, to actually position us for a stronger mortgage business, and part of that was just putting the infrastructure in place and then there were a lot of compliance changes with TRID. So there was a lot of investing to do to basically have a platform that really worked and that was much more electronic than digital. And while we were doing that, we were out trying to scale up the business and recruit more loan officers. So we've taken the LO count from about 350 at the beginning of the year, we headed up to 525. My guess is, we'll probably finish the year this year about 525. One of the things we're doing this year is kind of focusing more on conforming and more linkage to the branches and being more disciplined in terms of the exact LO demographic that we're looking for. So you'll see a little bit of churn in the count, and then I think you'll start to see us resume to grow again. But when we step back and look at the business, our scale was not where it needed to be overall and the channel is really limited to the retail LO channel and some direct-to-consumer digital and phone marketing that we were doing. So Franklin acquisition that we just announced today, Franklin American, really is a beautifully complementary acquisition to -- and right in the sweet spot of our strategy. So they have a $40 billion servicing portfolio. Our servicing portfolio today is $20 billion, so it triples the size, which is roughly the proportion that you should have off-balance sheet to on-balance sheet servicing. And it also brings new channels to us, the B2B channel, so the correspondent and wholesale channels and all of that volume is really conforming. So the retail channel tends to be maybe half conforming and half nonconforming. The correspondent channel will be much more conforming, which is really fee revenue. So we find it compelling from a financial standpoint, compelling from a strategic standpoint, and I think moves us quite a bit down the track in terms of having the mortgage business in the right place.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And solid deal metrics, 1.1x tangible, 2% accretion?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Yes. 2% in '19, 3% in 2020, less than 3-year burnback, so some great metrics, and our fee percentage takes a boost by 2%. So that's one thing people look at the model and say, I wish you had a little more fees while we bought the M&A shop last year. Now we've done mortgage. We've said we're also looking in the wealth space to kind of turbo charge some of the things we have going on there. So I think if we can find really high-quality franchises that fit with our culture and we think we can really leverage those capabilities, I think those are smart things to do. And the size is such that they don't really tie up a lot of capital, they can kind of be seen as bolt-ons and add-ons and help us get to the metrics that we're trying to get to faster.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And on the Commercial side, what are the fee revenue opportunities that you see?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Yes. So there, there's really 3 big areas. One I would broadly call Capital Markets, and I think we've really built up that business so that it's very strong and very high quality in terms of being able to compete with money centers and all the super regional banks and RE deals in terms of loan syndications. And we're in bond underwriting deals as well. There is more activities that we can engage in there as we continue to build out that business, so either getting deeper by having more force and more people as we build up our coverage groups, combined with broadening capabilities, I think there is nice potential for that business going forward. We also have a business which we call Global Markets, which is really interest rate and FX risk management capabilities, which we used to do in conjunction with RBS. And so we had to move off their platforms, stand up our own platform and then go out and recruit new people and have kind of a new approach to the business. There as well, I think, we're scratching the surface of having some, I think, great new capabilities and talent that's joined the company, and so you're going to see, I think, future growth and expansion into some more sophisticated products than what we've had before. And then lastly, it's -- the big sticky product area is cash management, and I think we've probably outgrown the market over the, I'd say, the last 3, 4 years, maybe we're high single digits and the natural rate of growth appears as maybe half of that at best, maybe 2% to 4%. And I think there is opportunity, as we continue to grow our loan book and our book of customers, to actually accelerate that once we put our new cash management platform in place, which will start to roll out late this year into the first half of next year. So one of the things we're excited about is when we get up into the bigger customers, we bump into the JPs and the big guys with their cash management platforms and all the bells and whistles they have. We have a very good platform for middle market companies. In fact, we won an award from Global Finance for having one of the best for middle market, but if we want to capture some of that opportunity with the bigger companies, then I think we had to move and take that step to make the investment and upgrade that platform. So we're excited about what that potential is for the business in 2019 and beyond.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Moving to the expense side. When we think about opportunities for banks on the expense side, branch networks seem ripe for rationalization. You've shown a willingness to prune and even exit markets. How should we think about the future potential for cost saves versus the constant need to invest in technology?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Sure. So I'd say, we've had about a 1200 branch count, 800 stand-alone and 400 in-stores, and that's slowly being rationalized. Maybe that's down 50 over the last 2, 3 years. And there is 2 things that are going on. One is to look for consolidations at the margin where we can make them work, but then I think more importantly is what we call our branch transformation program, which is to take kind of yesteryear's branches that had on average 4,300 square feet and lots of space dedicated for tellers and kind of reposition them as advice centers with the smart machines up front to handle transactions, maybe only one universal banker or teller-type individual and then a bunch of private meeting rooms where people can make appointments and see specialists. So the nature of the people in the branches has changed, the nature of what the branches are used for has changed, and, oh, by the way, those newly designed branches probably only need 2,200 square feet or less. So I think that's something that over time will continue to drive a reduction in the rentable square foot base, which will save us money combined with the closures where you get 100 cents on the dollar from what you close. And I think when you kind of go back to what I said about the mindset of self-funding, is we know we need to keep investing in digital, we know we need to keep investing in data and so extract some expense dollars that are no longer efficiently used to serve your customers and turn around and invest in the things -- how the customer wants to transact with you in the future, and so that's basically what we're doing.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Now that invest side, I think there is some question among investors. Will a bank of Citizens' size, and you're not a small bank, you're a big bank, but you have giant universal banks investing billions of dollars a year in technology. How will a bank your size be able to compete with them?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Yes, I think that's a very topical question these days because the biggest banks are pounding their chests about how great their brand is and how great the amount of money they're spending on technology, but they're also complex institutions, and there's a lot of things that they're doing, not just in consumer banking. They're doing a lot in investment banking and other things, which a fair amount of that money is directed that way. I think why I am confident that banks our size can continue to perform well is we typically run on vendor platforms that the industry is sharing, if you will. So if there is a number of regional banks on an FIS platform, for example, there's scale from that and there is demands on FIS to take care of all the needs that they see from multiple points of view and put that into the next release. So I think there is some very good vendor platforms out there that we take advantage of, but then kind of it's like cable, the last mile is really important of how you connect to your consumer. I do think that we can be nimble and really differentiate at that customer interface point. And I can give you an example, so we've had -- we've won an award from Javelin for having the best functionality of our mobile banking app for 4 years running. And last year, we ended up in a tie for first, BofA crept up and tied us. But how -- with all the money they can spend, how can we be in the same kind of conversation, and it really is being out, understanding your customer, talking to your customer, having focus groups and testing and learning and try to put really good functionality into your application. So anyway, I don't think there is a high correlation between size and efficiency ratio. So other things creep in when you get big that make it harder to manage, and I think banks our size can be flexible and nimble and can be very competitive.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Great, maybe shifting to capital. We're a few weeks away from the CCAR results. You said you have a goal of managing your capital ratios back down to peers' levels over time. What do you see as a destination in terms of CET1? And maybe remind us of your capital deployment priorities?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Sure. So we refreshed our medium-term targets that we had set some at the time of the IPO and then we've achieved those last year. So in January, we put new ones out and as part of those targets, we put a CET1 ratio of 10:10.25. I think what I'd say about that is, that's not a fixed destination. I think what you have to focus on is your relative position to where your peers go. And peers are making a lot of noise and they want to get lower than that. They want to get to 9%. I think there's no fundamental reason that we need to have a premium relative to peers. If you look at our credit losses under the CCAR stress test, we're actually slightly better than the median. So there's not a flaw in our business model that requires extra capital. I think we've been properly cautious in terms of bringing down that ratio on a glide path, just because we're relatively new, we have to gain confidence from stakeholders, including the rating agencies and regulators that we're running the bank well and that we can, over time, just excise that premium. Today, announcing the deal, it's not a bad thing to have a little bit of extra capital because, I think, right now we've been able to have loan growth that exceeds that of our peers. We've had close to 100% return of capital, so we're shareholder friendly in terms of what we're returning to our shareholders. And then we can squeeze in deals that use a little bit of that CET1 up. And so I think, we're on the glide path, we're managing it down, we'll keep an eye on where peers go, and we'll continue to move that down.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: So given your size, you're one of those banks between 50 and 250 (sic) [$50 billion and $250 billion] and that's in terms of assets. So we sort of got this 18-month period before the change in the CCAR would affect you. Once out of the process, how do you see that? Does it affect the speed of capital return? Does it -- is there an expense save? How do you see the impact of that?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Well, I think we're starting to institutionalize these processes and, therefore, can start to release some resources. It's kind of things that we see across the bank. We had a lot of work to do coming out of RBS, there was a lot of remediation and other regulatory issues that we were behind on and frameworks we had to build in compliance and things we had to do. Once you remediate old issues, you put your frameworks in place and you start to industrialize how they operate. You just don't need as many people. And so we've been benefiting, over time, we crested, maybe a couple of years ago, 18 months ago, and as we're coming out the other side and we're running the bank better, we're gaining some efficiencies there. So I think the CCAR process is similar in many respects to that.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: One of the things that we're hearing increasing concerns from investors on is the potential impact on capital and earnings from CECL accounting as it rolls on 2019 into 2020. How do you -- what's your view on that? And how it might impact?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: I think the industry in general believes that CECL is somewhat misguided, and that it is going to be procyclical. So what problem are you trying to solve and then you come up with a solution that actually doesn't solve the problem, in some ways makes it worse. But the ship sails and the pronouncement is the pronouncement. I think now we have to kind of do our best to understand how to implement it and what implications it has on the portfolios that we want to hold. And then, what implications it has on the capital position, and how is the Fed, in particular, going to deal with those extra reserves? Is it something that you get credit for in your loss scenarios? Or is it something that became, if it's a 10% bump up or 15% bump up in your reserves, is it just a new way to capture capital that you don't get the benefit of? So I'm optimistic that if you make the argument that, hey, the risks are the same, the accounting changed, but there shouldn't be a need for more capital just because the accounting changed, that shouldn't drive the capital requirement. I think we can -- the industry can make those arguments to the regulators, and usually the regulators are looking for the proper decisions, and kind of truth and justice usually prevail in those discussions. So there'll be a kind of a learning process and adjusting process, and I think we'll find ways to cope with it and manage it successfully.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Great. Last one from me before we shift to some audience questions. So your stock trades at a discount to regional bank peers, we see that as an opportunity. What do you think the market is missing in terms of valuation versus other regional banks? And what do you think you can do to change that?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Yes. Well, if you go back to the last couple of years, that wasn't the case. And if you actually go back to January, we had a premium. So I think we've fallen -- fallen off in terms of our valuation over the last, maybe 3 or 4 months. And we've seen that in the past, I think when risk tends to go off and people are a bit concerned about the outlook for a year, that often happens in the first half of the year because there's not enough quarters in the bank to demonstrate that you're able to execute and put up the good numbers. We've had, I think, a softer start to the year, almost every year since we've been a public company. I think what we've had happen later in the year is, "Okay, well, these guys continue to execute and they're putting up great numbers." And the market starts to look ahead to the next year, and I think your stock is ultimately going to be anchored in your numbers, where's your EPS going? Where's your return on equity going? And ours has moved -- has improved at a faster clip than our peer group. And ultimately, you're rewarded for that. So my view is we'll continue to execute. I think we're going to have a very solid outlook for this year, I think we had a very strong first quarter. I think we gave outlook guidance for second quarter, it's going to be very strong. And I think that The Street is moving numbers up on us in the second half of the year, much like happened last year. So my hope is that, ultimately, if we deliver, the stock should take care of itself. And I think there's -- the worry beads would be things like the LDR that we have as the screen -- or the cost of interest-bearing deposits going up may be at the higher end of peers. But I would say to that is that we still think there's accretive opportunities to put our capital to work and good loan portfolios that at the margin, it's still accretive to NIM and it's still accretive to our overall performance. And so if we have to pay up a little bit to get the deposit growth to fund the loan growth, and we're building out our franchise and taking on new customers that we can cross-sell our fee-based services to, that's ultimately a good thing. And we have the initiatives on the deposit side that, I think, will continue to have a positive impact. They don't -- there is many of them, and they're running simultaneously and they have gradual impact on things like Citizens Access, I think will have a positive impact at the highest marginal cost of the deposits that we're raising. So there's a number of things we have that, I think, will allow us to manage that cost arc in a positive way. But the market can -- there can be some folks who are skeptical about that, and we'll just have to demonstrate that we have a plan and we can execute that plan and the proof of the pudding will be in the eating.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Great. Okay, shifting to some audience questions. Now you have a medium-term target of 300 to 500 basis points of operating leverage annually, what gives you the confidence that you can achieve that?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Well, I think we've demonstrated that we've been able to do that on a consistent basis. And again, you start with, if you got 70% or so of your revenue in net interest income and you can grow your loan book at maybe nominal GDP plus 1 and you're asset-sensitive, then you get to a kind of 70% of your revenues are going to be growing at a pretty good clip. And then combined that with the fee potential of the franchise where we're immature still in some capabilities and we're making the investments and we're going to pull through the return on those investments, I think we should get a reasonably good, hopefully, faster than that growth on the fee side. So to me, it always starts with, can you drive revenue growth and deliver that top line growth because then it makes everything a lot easier, then you can continue to invest. And if we, on the expense side, continue to have this mindset of continuous improvement, I think we can constrain the rate of expense growth by continuing to seek those inefficient use of expense dollars and then invest in the digital, invest in the data, invest in the things of tomorrow and do that at a spread. And so last year, we had 10% revenue growth, 3% expense growth, 7% operating leverage. You're not going to be able to do that every year, but every year we've been a public company we've been able to stay within that 3 to 5 or better corridor. I don't really think we've exhausted the opportunity set to do that for the foreseeable future.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Great. This one says, what do you see as the most disruptive force in commercial banking -- in banking over the next 5 years?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: That's a hard one, if you -- to just single out one, there's certainly lots of ways to answer that. I'd say, really moving to that digital business model is a point of disruption that banks who execute well, can turn that into an opportunity and strengthen relationship with their customers and banks who fall behind can see their franchise value erode at a, probably a faster clip than used to occur. So in banking, typically things evolve, there's evolutionary change, not revolutionary change and you could be in a group or the pack that's following behind the leaders and never fall too far behind in your business model, adjust, and you sustain the value of your franchise. I think we're at a point, and I had a conversation with Ginni Rometty of IBM about this, who thinks we're at one of those every 25 years, there's major technological change that alters the way consumers behave and interact with companies and how technology is utilized and how companies need to operate, and we're in one of those periods now with the use of data and things moving digital. And so making sure you have talent in your organization, who can see around the corners, work with partners to really stay on the front foot in that vein is really, really important. And I think if you get that wrong or you fall too far behind, that can start to erode your franchise value.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Just to follow up on that, so right now, the vision you've got a multichannel offering with the branch banking, mobile, online and now you have Citizens Access, which is presumably going to run in parallel. Does there come a point where they converge? And how do you see that happening?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Yes, it could be. We'll see. So right now, our deposit system that we run for the core franchise is stable and good and solid. The one that we're running on is a newer version. It's also an FIS platform, but it's kind of the latest and greatest version. And so it allows us to do some things that, I think, we'll test and we'll learn and we'll see, whether it's worth converging those platforms down the road. So that's one of the things that I like about that whole Citizens Access initiative is you get to try out your personalization in terms of using data. You just get the muscle that you need to compete 5 years down the road, and you're doing it in a very concerted effort with a team that's focused on that and those learnings can then be ported back in to the core franchise.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I have a follow-up here on the deal announcement today. Talk a bit about -- I'd ask, basically, why Franklin American? And why now?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: I believe that Franklin American is an exceptionally well-run company with a very strong reputation in the marketplace. One of our board members, Hoddy Hanna, who's Chair and CEO of Howard Hanna Real Estate Services, probably I think the third biggest private mortgage originator in the country, is a client of Franklin American and raves about their level of service, the quality of their technology, the quality of their people. So I think you have to start with that. It's not just let's do enough to the numbers where we can buy something at 1:1 and the math is going to work. If we want to get scale on the servicing side, and we want to diversify the origination capabilities that we have, who's out there that's really a high-quality franchise and somebody that we know, that we respect in the marketplace, and this was an opportunity that came along, and I think nothing ever comes along exactly when you want it to come along. It's the owner of that business. It's a 100% owned by an individual, feels it's time that he's ready to sell the business. You have to respond when the property's on the market. So I think it's actually a good time to be buying. I think that there's a bit of a hedge that the servicing -- as rates are moving up, the servicing becomes more valuable and maybe there's a little reduction in the origination capability, but if you're thinking long term and you're thinking, what do we need in the mortgage business to really be a factor and run a great business for the next 20 years, property like this comes along, you jump on it, you buy it, you execute it and, again, it's not so much money that it impacts any of our ratios or what we're doing from a capital management standpoint.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: A couple of follow-up questions on the stock price conversation. Pointing basically that the recent underperformance seems to start with the Manafort stories. You came out pretty quick -- pretty strongly that day and basically said that there is no there, there, I think. So to the extent of it, any additional conversations with regulators or updates?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Well, I mean, I guess, what you could -- if there were a problem, would we be announcing the deal today?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Right.

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: So I'll just -- ask yourself that question. If you go back and look at our regulatory disclosures and how they've gotten thinner and thinner over time, we can't comment on our ratings publicly, but there's enough breadcrumbs out there that you can figure out that we've done a lot of good work to get the bank in a great position from a risk and regulatory and compliance standpoint, and we're at the point where we can go out and play offense and do deals. And as I think we said in that release, that we think our AML capabilities are very, very strong.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Great. Couple of questions, somewhat related to the deal and that. With the changes to Dodd-Frank, does it change how you view bank M&A going forward?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: No, I think you'll probably see an uptick in bank M&A, like you just saw with [Fifler's] deal. So I think there'll be some of our peers who've been acquisitive in the past will look to do bank deals. I think what we've said for Citizens is, we want to focus on a running the bank better and getting organic growth, which we've been able to do and there is more of that to get, and then build out our capabilities and focus on building up those fee franchises. And I still think that's the winning strategy for us.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Question on competitors entering your market. So Chase is entering key markets like Boston, how do you view competition playing out?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: There's never a shortage of competition in any of the markets that we serve. There's plenty of banks out there, and what I would say is, that's why the customer experience and becoming a trusted adviser are paramount because whether it's a fintech disruptor, whether it's a money center bank, whether it's a big tech attempted disrupter, you will be able to hold on to your clients if your clients trust you and they are very satisfied with your services and that you're helping them on life's journey if they're an individual, or you're helping them be successful if they're corporate. And so that's really where we're directing our investment. I would say, we've seen big banks come into these markets before. Citi had a similar strategy about 10 years ago. They were in Boston. They were in Philadelphia. They pulled up their stakes. They're out of all those markets. It's not that easy, ultimately, to go in when all the prime locations have been taken. The people, the quality people are going to be well tended to and the banks are going to protect their investment in their people. And the amount of, I think, effort that we put into communities in terms of not only financial contribution but having the mass and the force to make a difference and be at every event with volunteers who are making these communities better, that goes a long way to protecting your position in the marketplace. So JP can come into those markets, they'll just compete, just like all the other people we compete against. I don't think we're quaking in our boots. I think we're confident that we have a lot of good tools and a lot of good position and strong franchises in Boston and Philadelphia.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: This one says can you tell us -- can you update us on what's going on with your relationship with Apple?

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Yes, I think we've said all along that we have a very strong relationship with Apple. I think we're aligned around the importance of customer experience and we continue to receive very positive feedback on Apple. And I can't comment on why. If Goldman is trying to insinuate that they're going to broaden their relationship with Apple, that's not anything that I would have a perspective on. I think all I can comment on is our relationship with Apple, and I think it's a very strong and healthy relationship.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Great. Bruce, thank you very much. It's been excellent.

BRUCE W. VAN SAUN: Okay. Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5VRC-RKS1-F021-60BK-00000-00Citizens told to 'quit bureaucratic EU MONSTER' as bloc backs controversial Internet law2019-03-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:35ZLexisNexisCitizens told to 'quit bureaucratic EU MONSTER' as bloc backs controversial Internet lawAurora Bosotti

EUROPEAN citizens were urged to pressure national governments to "follow the Brexit example" and quit the European Union as EU legislators approved a controversial Internet copyright law in Strasbourg.

European parliamentarians on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved articles 11 and 13 of the European Union's controversial online copyright directive. The new regulation was devised to reign in the power of big tech companies like YouTube and Twitter to give them more responsibility to monitor and remove copyrighted material from their platforms. But speaking ahead of the vote, Polish MEP Stanislaw Zóltek warned the directive would introduce censorship worse than "in Communist countries" as he urged citizens to pressure governments to quit the bloc like Britain. 

Related articles 'Scared' EU admit Theresa May is 'devoid of any HUMAN skill' Piers Morgan FALLS OUT with Remainer MP in FIERY Brexit clash

Addressing colleagues in the Strasbourg chamber, Mr Zóltek said: "This version of the directive will still introduce censorship at levels we didn't have in Communist countries.

"Let's look at the text and see what it means - there's no point trying to convince members here. most people already have their opinion fixed. So let me turn at the citizens of Europe.

"Citizens of Europe, if you don't want to lose the rest of your freedom then force governments of your country to leave the European Union.

"Start Italexit, Polexit - take an example from Brexit."

LISTEN HERE: Latest Brexit news from the Express.co.uk Final Countdown podcast

Brexit news: Zóltek urged citizens to quit the bloc to maintain their Internet freedom

Mr Zóltek continued: "Let's create a real union of Europe, a union of nations, an innovative and newer union.

"What is stopping you voting against those voting in favour of this?"

During Brexit talks, Poland repeatedly offered support to the British Government, going as far as proposing a five-year time limit to the Irish backstop despite opposition from top Eurocrats.

Poland's foreign minister Jacek Czaputowicz, who championed the bid to break the Brexit deadlock in January, claimed Irish intransigence had resulted in a "game of chicken with two cars hurtling toward each other, and we will have a frontal collision".

Speaking to Polish newspaper Rzeczpospolita, Mr Czaputowicz added: "As a consequence, Ireland will lose most and it will have the duty of organising the EU external border with Northern Ireland."

Related articles Brexit news latest: What is a Norway style Brexit? UK Brexit options Brexit: Could No Deal Brexit happen on April 13?

Theresa May is expected to hold a series of indicative votes on Wednesday to test the waters in regards to which Brexit solution would have enough backing among MPs after she failed to secure their support for her Brexit deal.

But the Prime Minister could still manage to snatch a deal with the EU before the no deal deadline set for April 12 after diplomats and officials have revealed that the Northern Ireland-only backstop could be used to avoid a hard border if Britain crashes out the EU without a deal.

The deal is believed to be the same one rejected as unworkable in earlier efforts to find a solution.

High-level talks between Dublin, London and the European Commission have seen the proposals raised on numerous occasions. The pitch could be used by Brussels as leverage for resuming trade negotiations if Mrs May fails to win the support of MPs for her draft EU withdrawal agreement

Speaking to Politico an unnamed EU official, who was decidedly vague, said: "We are in intense discussions with the Irish authorities about these matters.

"We will of course continue and intensify these discussions over the coming days."

Related articles Who is Oliver Letwin? Can he spark a snap election? Brexit news: How indicative votes were used before - but meant NOTHING Brexiteer MP Mark Francois claims Europe is FREE because of Britain

Corporate Participants

Citrix Systems, Inc.- COO and CFO

* Geir Ramleth

Citrix Systems, Inc.- Chief Strategy Officer and SVP and General Manager of Workspace Services

Citrix Systems, Inc.- VP and General Manager, Windows App Delivery

Citrix Systems, Inc.- Group VP & GM, Mobile Platform Group

Citrix Systems, Inc.- SVP & GM, Delivery Networks Business Unit

* Carlos Sartorius

Citrix Systems, Inc.- SVP, Worldwide Sales & Services

* Chris Hylen

Citrix Systems, Inc.- SVP and General Manager, Mobility Apps

Citrix Systems, Inc.- President and CEO

Conference Call Participants

William Blair & Company- Analyst

Robert W. Baird & Company, Inc. - Analyst

Barclays Capital - Analyst
