Drexel Hamilton - Analyst

* Sanjit Singh

Morgan Stanley - Analyst

Presentation

DAVID HENSHALL, COO AND CFO, CITRIX SYSTEMS, INC.: All right, so let's get going here today. We have a nice, full room here, and there's a whole bunch of people joining us via webcast. So I would just like to start off, as always, and say welcome. Thanks, everyone, for joining us at Citrix Synergy 2015.

I think this is probably the seventh year in a row that we have included a financial analyst meeting in conjunction with our Synergy event. We think it just leverages a lot of the activities that are going on, give you a much broader perspective of the organization.

Hopefully, those of you that are here had a chance to sit in on the morning keynote this morning. There is a keynote tomorrow morning as well. And more importantly, just having the ability to have spent time with our customers, our partners, and the broader part of the Citrix team to get a better understanding of the types of challenges that customers face, how we are addressing those with solutions, et cetera. So please take advantage of that.

And for those of you joining us via webcast, all of the major keynotes will be streamed on our website. If they are not up there already, they will be shortly. So please take the opportunity to cover that. I think it is great context, shows you a lot of what we are up to these days from a product point of view, operationally and corporate.

So the idea here is, similar to prior years, is that we talk in the keynotes about a pretty high level, and this is about making it a little bit more operational, taking it down a click and being very specific, specific about the product areas that we are operating in, how we are competing in individual categories, how we are thinking about solutions on a broader solution basis, how we are bringing these technologies to customers, and give you the opportunity to interact with the team more broadly.

So I will kick off here in a few minutes and talk about Citrix from a tops-down point of view, fully focused on financials and the operating plan. After that, I will call up Geir Ramleth. Geir is a new member of the organization. He is our Chief Strategy Officer and Senior Vice President and General Manager of Workspace Services.

Geir is going to take a little bit of a different spin and talk more about security. We've got a lot of questions coming from this audience to better articulate how do you fit into a broader security context, what does that mean from a Citrix point of view. So he is going to talk just for a few minutes about that and try to be a little bit more specific around security. And then we will drill into individual product areas on a more granular basis.

Bill Burley, longtime Citrix veteran, who is our head of Windows app delivery, talk about everything we are doing on a XenApp and desktop front. Brian Dye, who runs mobile app delivery, will be here. Klaus Oestermann, Senior Vice President and General Manager of our delivery networking business; a lot of exciting things going on with NetScaler and CloudBridge. He will take you down all of those details.

After that, Carlos Sartorius, our new SVP of Worldwide Sales and Services, we will talk about customers, talk about routes to customers and be much more specific about where we win, where we have got challenges, and really what we are doing about it going forward, all in driving higher productivity for our teams and much higher customer success across the board.

And Chris Hylen, who is the Senior Vice President and General Manager of our mobility apps business, talk a lot about all these critical services that we demoed, many of them today, and how it fits into the broader Citrix portfolio, not only as individual technologies, but as critical elements of many of our broader solutions.

We will take a break for those of you here in the room. And then all of the speakers, plus Mark Templeton, our President and CEO, will be available for Q&A discussion. And then those of you that are here, we welcome you to join us in person at a reception that we will be having just right around the quarter here.

So with that, let's jump right in. Obviously, there's a few statements today that are forward-looking in nature. And they are, of course, pursuant to Safe Harbor provisions and the risks that can be found on our website and within our SEC filings.

So as I said, I am going to spend a little bit more time talking about financials and operations. I know that there is a lot of familiarity with the business in this room, but there's a number of you that just haven't been that close to Citrix for a while. And so we just spend a couple of minutes giving context around how we got to where we are today.

This story that we talked about this morning is really not new for Citrix. It is the continuing evolution of a message that we have been on and a core belief that we have had for many, many years.

So when you take a step back and look at Citrix by the numbers, last year we were about a $3.1 billion organization. We operate with between 9,000 and 10,000 employees around the globe. We have official offices in 36 countries. And we are fortunate to work with about 10,000 partners around the globe, being able to service customers in well over 100 countries. So we are pretty much everywhere our customers need us to be.

And that partner network, many of which are here this week, so hopefully you have a chance to interact with them, includes everything from the largest global systems integrators that are focused on major transformation efforts with our customers, down through more regional service providers to allow even SMB-type engagement with our customers.

We've got a broad portfolio of solutions that we've built up over the years to be able to address the needs of our customers. And we operate with a leading market share across all the major categories and have been recognized as a leader in some of the new, emerging areas like enterprise mobility, enterprise file sharing, et cetera.

But as I said, this isn't necessarily a new story. This is a continuation of a journey that we have been on for a long time. In fact, for many, many, many years, we have had this fundamental belief, this belief that work is not a place, but it's something you do. And giving employees the capabilities to be productive on their terms raises that productivity substantially, creates a much higher level of engagement, and the obvious financial benefits for the end customer.

So when you look way back, back -- a little over 10 years ago, we talked about remote access, because that is what the technology of the day enabled us to do. It was either delivering the client/server application over a wide area network to enhance performance, or just simply road warriors and people needing to dial in to access their corporate intranet.

That has expanded as Web architectures became much more prevalent. Things were being delivered inside of a browser. And that is why we broadened out to include delivery networking, to effectively do the same types of things for Web apps that we have been doing for client/server apps for all these years: securing, optimizing, enhancing and managing, et cetera.

A number of years ago when virtualization, of course, became much more mainstream, for the first time ever, customers were able to disaggregate the pieces of their infrastructure and reconnect them in a way that was much more flexible and driving the types of business benefits that they needed to have. And then, obviously, over the last couple of years, we have been in this world that is characterized, obviously, by mobility, broad proliferation of devices, cloud services, et cetera. And so we have been going through this pivot as an organization to really build up our mobile side. And we have been talking about that to you for the last couple of years as the broad pivot towards workspace services. And you put this all over the broad umbrella of a software-defined workspace.

So in simple terms, our mission is to provide our customers with digital tools and services to mobility-transform their business, to give employees the ability to consume IT as a service, regardless of device, location, network, et cetera, enhancing productivity and enhancing financial and business benefits for customers. That's a journey we have been on for a long time, and that is driving everything we do and everything we plan on doing in the future.

And when you step back, you look at this from a financial point of view, this is a chart that I personally have been using for a dozen years now, and using it to describe the broad evolutions of the organization and some of the things going on around us that has really forced and allowed the Company to respond and react to evolve to all of those changing forces. I talked about them just a minute ago -- access, collaboration, networking, et cetera, et cetera -- and deliver really consistent up-and-to-the-right type financial results from a 1000-foot view.

It's also allowed us, through this journey, to broaden the available market. As the types of technology requirements for our customers have changed pretty dramatically, it has allowed us to address adjacent market opportunities necessary to fundamentally deliver against all of their requirements. And you look back, in 2004, we were the dominant player in a midsize but slow-growing market called Windows apps delivery. And as we went through that journey that I was just describing a few minutes ago, that expanded into new areas like delivery networking, collaboration, communications, mobile, et cetera.

Last year, that was about a $16 billion opportunity. When we look forward and take a fairly conservative lens on some of those individual markets, it points to a roughly $25 billion opportunity by 2018. So we think we are operating in a lot of great, importance markets across the technology landscape. We think we have emerging or leading positions across many of those. And, really, from a differentiation standpoint, we are stitching together these technologies in a way that create broad solutions for customers, solutions that solve much broader problems, that are differentiated and defensible in the marketplace, and just focused on adding value.

Also during this time, you have seen the evolution of Citrix as a company and just the distribution of where our revenue is coming from and the various pieces. And this chart just shows the stack bars of, in this case, our business units right now and how the business has evolved just over the last decade or so as we have continued on this journey.

That light-blue set of bars down at the bottom is workspace services, and for the majority of that history has represented Windows app delivery. That was XenApp and XenDesktop. Great business, growing about 10% CAGR all-in over the last 10 years, and providing a tremendous foundation of what we do.

Windows architecture is still the predominant infrastructure in most of our customers. And so even though they are adopting new things -- cloud-based, mobile, et cetera -- that long tail of Windows is incredibly important for our customers, and being able to deliver those apps in the most secure, managed, available way is necessary. And then, of course, you look at across mobility apps, consulting and delivery networking, building out the rest of our business over the last decade, allowing us to grow up to about a 14% CAGR over that period of time.

But the shape of the business has changed pretty dramatically as well. Back at the beginning, we were selling about 50% of total revenue in that year, coming off of new products and licenses, the new licenses that we had to sell each and every quarter, supported by some level of, at the time, software license update in that yellow bar.

The broadest shift over the last 10 years has been the move towards SaaS, the increasing importance of holistic maintenance offerings for our customers, and then just generally shrinking that new product license that needs to be sold each quarter. So you will hear this a lot when you talk to our customers this week, if you are here in Orlando. But we hear this constantly. And it comes in a number of different ways, but basically what they are saying is, I need to mobilize my business. And you saw those videos this morning, some of our innovation award winners, of putting that into practice, because it's not simply enabling a device to access email, but it's about fundamentally mobility-transforming their entire infrastructure, the infrastructure so that it can be consumed as an IT service, consumed across device types, across location types, but changing the way that they work.

And that is coming in a number of different forms, but that is the fundamental message you are hearing. And when you talk to our customers this week, you will hear them repeat that over and over again.

But it is slightly different when you are talking to a CEO versus a CIO. There's a lot of pressures that they are both having to deal with, right? The pressures that, frankly, face all of our customers across every industry. We talked a lot about just the broadening heterogeneity of device types. It has gone from a single device to it doesn't matter; it's any-ness, the underlying complexity which is in their IT infrastructure.

For years, I used to describe, like, the data center as an archaeological dig. And what I meant by that was that customers were adopting new technologies, but in many cases, were really not unplugging what was already there. So if you go and you meet with one of our big, big customers, what you will hear from them is layer upon layer of successive technologies. They are still adding value to the organization, and they are still working.

And that is what they have to manage, that increasing complexity: mainframe, client/server, minicomputer, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera, all adding value to the enterprise, all creating more complexity over time. Workforce diversification, whether that is generational or geographic; change, of course, around -- all around us; offshoring M&A, et cetera, and security. And security just being the accountability that Mark talked about this morning, but it's pervasive now. And it's not just a check the box from a regulatory point of view. It's business-critical, and people need to think about it in those dimensions.

So of course, the CEO is purely focused on how do I grow my business faster; how do I improve productivity; how do I integrate M&A and improve my competitive position? The CIO has got those concerns, but he is thinking about how implementation. How do I solve the problems with data security? How do I keep everything within my network? How do I manage user experience in such a way that the users are actually going to consume the technology that I give them versus just using a workaround? Which is an ever-increasing problem, pretty much across the board. And then, doing that in a way that is agnostic to device types, app, data, all in a single low-cost way.

So same type of context, same type of pressures, but coming at the problems from slightly different angles. And it is our job to really bridge those worlds to make that a reality across the board.

And so when you talk to them and you hear the conversations, they generally fall into a number of buckets that I call business initiatives, the things that they are worried about right now that they can put projects around, they could put defined budgets and accountability. But all these things, whether it is BYO, flex-working, security, continuity, they all have that common element that is mobilizing the business, to be able to separate people from their physical workspace and reconnect that on demand. And that is what we do. These are the types of business initiatives that our customers are focused on that we are enabling.

And just to put a fine point on that, this is some data that we looked at about a year ago, as well as some industry reports. And it calls out and just points out what is now fairly obvious, the fact that people are working from a number of different devices. The average person now uses three. Generally, that is a phone, tablet, the laptop. Doesn't matter what device they have; doesn't matter if it's five or 10 or 20. What matters is they need to be able to consume information on demand in the same managed, secure way.

In fact, if I look at Citrix as an organization today, we now have not a single managed device outside of 50% of our computers. All the phones, all the tablets, those are all BYO. So we have more than twice as many unmanaged devices as we have managed devices in our infrastructure.

Multiple locations -- two-thirds of people are now working outside of the office. That is not just checking email, but that is actually engaging in your normal business outside of a single location.

App proliferation -- the average customer in our customer base has over 200 apps. What I talked about just a minute ago was that archaeological dig, and that is true. To give you one simple example, Citrix is a relatively simple infrastructure. We obviously consume all of our own technologies. We live this message. Yet we still have over 150 apps in our infrastructure for 9,000 people. When you talk to our really big customers, that number goes up into the many, many, many thousands. And so the cost and complexity of managing that is really pronounced.

And then, the unmanaged data problem: The studies have shown that it is over 80% of large organizations have unmanaged cloud storage. I think we all know that number is probably closer to 100% when you look at the workarounds that people have used to just make their jobs easier. They haven't had the capabilities in the past to be able to consume business information in different ways, so they have a Dropbox account or some other type of service that allows them to work around the corporation.

And so data loss prevention, IP security, et cetera, is a huge problem. And being able to manage all those together is, again, an extension of what we do.

So as I have talked about a number of times, and we will spend more time over the next couple of hours drilling into, we have market-leading solutions across all of these key critical areas, whether that is virtualization, networking, mobility, et cetera, to really give customers the tools to fix these problems. And as we talk about them, we will show you how they compete and they operate individually within their market categories, and then, of course, how we differentiate across the board to create broader solutions.

And as Mark was saying this morning, there's really three fundamental issues that underlie our strategy: the idea of experiences, security, and flexibility. Experiences -- the technology has to be consumable. People have to use them. The experience needs to look more like a consumer product. It needs to give you the type of productivity that is not just another IT service that is being forced on employees, but is something that you want to use -- you want to use because it works. That is experiences.

Security, as we have talked about a number of times, and Geir will spend more time with, is embedded and contextual. There is no such thing as a single security model, but it needs to change based on the types of data that people are accessing, maybe the scenarios, the types of device location, et cetera. And it has to be able to be resilient across that framework.

And then, of course, any app, any cloud, any consumption delivery, and that is flexibility. That is the any/any/any/ampersand message that Mark was using earlier today. Experience, security, and flexibility. And you will hear us talk much more about that going forward.

If you look at what Chris's team has been doing in that area, that's one of the great growth opportunities for ShareFile and GoToMeeting. What we are doing to turn the ship there, especially in the virtualization area, where the security and experience and flexibility are paramount. And so that's how I'd answer your question, if it helps.

MICHAEL TURITS, ANALYST, RAYMOND JAMES & ASSOCIATES, INC.: Michael Turits from Raymond James. Dave, everything has decelerated a bit recently. And as you go forward now, how do you think about the growth opportunities from different segments, including Windows App Delivery, which is the subsegment, at least directionally? And a follow-up question to that is: when you think about investing, given that you are going to expand margins, how do you think about prioritizing those investments across different growth opportunities?

DAVID HENSHALL: Let me take the second part of the question first. As a team we talk a lot about where the opportunity is long-term -- what businesses need to have incremental investment to drive growth over a multiyear period of time, and what businesses, frankly, are just in more mature markets. And we are optimizing for greater profit.

And then that takes on a number of different flavors. In some cases we take the common developments, and we move some of it into lower-cost locations. And that's one way to bring down costs while maintaining the base.

In other cases we'll take technologies, and we'll just fold them into others to be able to optimize the cost envelope, but leverage the core capabilities into something larger. That just reduces the number of moving parts. So it's a little bit of all of the above.

When we think about the growth opportunity -- and I talked a little bit about the TAM size -- the aggregate TAM of the categories we are participating in right now is somewhere north of 10%. It depends on where you look at it and how much weight you want to put on the categories, but it's north of 10% growth in the underlying opportunity for where we are participating right now.

Specific to Windows App Delivery, the best data that we get from industry analysts shows that it's a flat to low growth market overall. So our business has been on a new license basis clearly in transition. It's been decelerating in a couple of categories and declining in a couple of categories. And then we talked about this underlying shift towards new, more consumption-based, and whatnot.

You might not have caught it, but I had actually said that last quarter we actually delivered a year-on-year increase in licenses. It was a double-digit growth in licenses year on year, even though total revenue decelerated. And that's just a statement about the mix, because a CSP license, for example, would take a little over two years to be the same in-period financial impact as, obviously, a new perpetual license of one of those.

So it's a little bit of both. I think that the investments that we've made in things to really focus on -- whether it's midmarket VDI, vertical attach, project-based use cases -- that type of segmentation is going to be important going forward, because there's places where we just haven't competed.

And so when we talk about things like WorkspacePod, Workspace Cloud, and others, really, the idea there is how do you extract away complexity from customers to allow them to go faster? Changing the cost and complexity profile is really, really important. So we are going to do a little bit of both of all those.

But I think that probably the last thing I would say is as a team, we are much more focused and clear around segments and understanding within each of our businesses -- where we are not selling more of a solution approach, there is individual market segments that have different ways to differentiate, different growth rates, different opportunities, different go-to-market -- and being more specific about the areas that we definitely want to compete in and doing those end-to-end.

And the places that we don't think we have inherent leverage, we're just not going to participate in that. And that's just more of the evolution around clarity that you are hearing over the course of the restructuring and beyond. Anything you would add to that, Mark?

MARK TEMPLETON: Really not much beyond -- just to say that I think that when markets mature, the first thing you have to do is segment them, because they will grow like mad on a horizontal basis until they get to a maturity, where the only way to keep the primary demand going is to segment them, and -- with demographics, psychographics, all of those kinds of methodologies.

So what we've done in the Windows App Delivery space, in fact, is say: okay, where is the value proposition that's attached to the long tail of Windows and Windows apps and desktops. Where is that? And that is in government, healthcare, banking, and engineering-related areas. And the reason is some combination of security of IP, lack of control of endpoints, and lack of control of the workforce that's at that endpoint. Maybe contractors, maybe employees, etc.

So by using our -- what we call our relationships and combining what we call hero apps, hero devices, and hero use cases, that's how we can actually attack these verticals without having a vertical sort of oriented organization and business.

And then when Bill is prioritizing the feature set for the next feature pack or the next release of XenApp, he knows exactly which segments those things are feeding. And we know exactly how to drive demand with those features. That's very different from how we got here.

How we got here was by being the primary driver of demand in a market that we invented from scratch, all right, and approaching it in a horizontal way. In sort of a mea culpa, I believe that I -- we as a company, but I as being accountable for it, missed the turn from the horizontal to much more of a vertical and long-tail kind of a turn.

And then I think if you look at the commodity end of the marketplace, it's being more and more served by a Windows server, which -- you know, it always has been; it's just that it's served, I think, more robustly and more directly today. And I think we have opportunity to do products that can enhance the commodity end of the marketplace and serve as a land-expand kind of process that, frankly, is what got us here.

We met with our partners on Monday, and they talked extensively about their experience around how we would sell a customer a small solution, and it worked. They wanted to expand it with more users or more apps, and then got invited back to make it -- to put it in more places or expand the number of use cases. And I think we have -- I think that's where our opportunity is in the so-called Windows App Delivery space.

KIRK MATERNE, ANALYST, EVERCORE ISI: Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI. Maybe to expand on that a little bit, Mark, just from a channel perspective -- obviously, when you -- I'd say some of the feedback from the channel the last couple of years has been that -- alienate is maybe not the right word, but there's been some give-and-take between you and the channel. And perhaps it was this idea that you were looking at things horizontally, and perhaps you should have been focusing more on the channels to go to vertical.

I guess, when you try to sort of catch up in that regard, how long does that take? Meaning -- you guys have a big product set, but to get them really focused on a more vertical market, that's a little bit more solution-oriented. There will be some channel partners that could probably make that jump; there's some that can't.

What should we expect from the channel over the next 12 months from you guys? And if they are able to make that leap, should we see your actual professional services revenue maybe level off a little bit? Because the professional services revenue has gone up really nicely, but I'd say in some respects you probably want to be handing off more of that revenue to your channel partners, if you are getting more strategic with some of your customers. So could you just talk about that a little bit? How key is that to making your top-line goals for the next year or two?

MARK TEMPLETON: So I think if you look at our classic channel partners, the platinum partners, I think they feel loved. They feel profitable. They will ebb and flow with changes in policies and programs, and we don't always get it right.

I think the gold and silver partner community, we have not shown the kind of incentives and love for. And part of that is because of the more -- the greater focus we have had on strategic selling. So I think that, again, it's in conjunction with the opportunity we talked about in Windows App Delivery: being more use-case-oriented, doing some things that can fill the more commodity end of the marketplace. That's how we can engage with them and reengage with them.

Certainly Workspace Cloud has a partner-centric message around it, and we think that's going to be a big incentive for them to reengage. We will have to do some re-incentivizing. Fernando -- who's not here, but I'm sure Carlos talked about the reorganization that he did in the Americas that really separated out the direct touch from the channel-centric organization. I think that makes a big difference, and I think it will take us kind of all year to see that.

I also would say, Kirk, that every one of these partners -- very few of them are, like, fully horizontal. That's how they make their money, by repeating. So they are already there. It's just that we don't feed them that way, all right?

CARLOS SARTORIUS: No, no -- that's correct. As a matter of fact, I think the platinum gave us a lot of feedback -- that we needed to verticalize, and that we needed to support them with the solutions, with the marketing, with the collateral, with some of the specific features that they need.

I think that if you look into more, like Mark was saying, the silver and gold, we are doing a lot of work around enabling them, working together with them, and reinvigorating the channel by -- in the case of Americas, the way Fernando did it, as well as in EMEA. We have now a very much concentrated effort on organization that's working with them. And it's part of the structures that I talked about. If you remember, in the pyramid, we have a CDM FSMs that are working together with the channel to develop customers, to develop opportunities, and really drive that market.

So I think you're going to be hearing a lot more from us as far as making sure we have the right products for them to be successful, the right enablement, the right support. And also, you mentioned about the services -- I think as we continue to support the enterprise global accounts and drive the top of the pyramid, you will still see our services growing. But we also won't, in certain countries and in certain places, enable them for them to be able to do the services, because we might not even have the presence, or we are working on opening emerging countries. If you look in EMEA, Russia, Turkey, Israel -- a number of different countries that we've seen potential, and we are doing it through the channel.

MARK TEMPLETON: If there's one thing that I would like to change as fast as possible, it's to have the products -- and you saw some of them today -- that can be bought and not sold. Okay? And by the way, those are the products that channel partners love the most, because they become the most profitable.

So I think what we've done is take the complexity bar and radically lowered it. So I think that's going to change the economic model for the partners we already have -- doing the things they already do, but also we'll open up the engagement of the silvers and golds in a whole new way.

And we didn't talk about WorkspacePod today, but we're not going to really spend any time on it here at the conference. But just stay tuned on that, because that's another way to make this really simple and get greater reach --

KIRK MATERNE: The partners.

MARK TEMPLETON: Yes. It's very partner-friendly.

KARL KEIRSTEAD, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK: Karl Keirstead at Deutsche Bank. David, you talked about some of the main elements of the restructuring. It feels like many of them are behind you, at least started and well underway.

The one that isn't yet, though, is the portfolio streamlining, which you mentioned is, quote, in process. I thought it might be a good idea for you and Mark maybe to use this occasion to hit refresh on that process. How comprehensive will it be? And generally, what's the framework you're going to use to approach those decisions?

DAVID HENSHALL: Yes. I'd say, without going into granular detail, the highest or the tops-down view of that would be understanding with clarity what markets are critical to delivering the strategy; what products are critical to be able to compete, both on a category basis and as elements of solutions; and then being very thoughtful about everything that doesn't fall cleanly into those buckets.

The second click on that from a go-to-market point of view-- and we did this going into this year -- is understand: what is truly core? What products do we want to have a defined go-to-market motion against -- things that will include everything from demand gen out through enablement, etc.? What products that we'll we want to be sold purely as an attach motion versus trying to go after a red ocean market, and then what things would we just have as opportunistics?

And so the things that don't fall cleanly into those areas have either been end-of-lifed, and that's happened in a number of smaller products; there are cases where we've taken products and made them into just feature elements, where the technology becomes embedded -- so it's no longer a name, a brand, a go-to-market motion, etc. And then in some cases they would fall into those categories that I just mentioned.

So that's the process that -- it's soft. You can't just do this overnight, simply because you've got customers that are on a lot of these technologies, products that we've sold in the past. If it's an integration solution, that takes time to do that thoughtfully.

So it's not just another technology in the box, if you will. And because of that, that process is multi-quarter in nature. Part of the question about the larger business units -- I think we tried to articulate that today, just to help understand: here are the primary product lines within the business units -- how they operate independently and interdependently across the organization. And I think that overlap is -- you can quantify that differently depending on which product you are talking about. I mentioned a couple of examples around, like, data platform and mobility.

The data fabric is really what differentiates mobility from an EMM vendor to a large degree. The fact that we have integrated collaboration makes the Worx family a truly productive suite of tools. 20% to 30% of NetScaler comes from attaching to a virtualization sale. And on and on and on.

And that's the interdependence piece. And I think that actually gets much more pronounced as you look forward into the Workspace Cloud era, where things are becoming delivered as more a la carte services, if you will, and just giving customers that ability.

So there's still work to do, because not everything fits cleanly into that definition. And that's why it's ongoing. There are things that we are continuing to look at.

KARL KEIRSTEAD: So just to be clear, when you talk about portfolio streamlining, are you talking about individual products? Or are you also giving consideration to broader and larger business units, as well? Or is it both?

DAVID HENSHALL: Well, I think it's -- there's a little bit of a tactical and a strategic answer to that. When we talk about it, it's more of a product technology standpoint up; but as you would imagine, from a governance standpoint, we are always thinking about it with the Board on a tops-down basis to really understand the markets and the categories we are in. And so those are conversations that happen on a regular basis.

KARL KEIRSTEAD: Okay. Thanks for the update.

MARK TEMPLETON: Yes. And I'd say that we talk about streamlining, like, on the conference call, etc., the quarterly call, we really are talking about the technology, the products, etc., and how to actually put them in the right state -- off the SKU list or on the shelf.

You'll see, for example, there are some of the products that we think are better sold at the cloud service, but we haven't had a vehicle to sell into cloud service. And so they become -- they will become Workspace Cloud services that can be bought kind of all by themselves and will be easier to offer that way than as a premise-based service.

So I think we have -- so a lot of the work that we have done is to reduce the investment in those products to the point where they are -- we're readying them to be plugged into CWC, to be offered. And what you will see -- I don't know how many of you have AWS or Azure accounts, but if you do, you see there is a constant flow of communications around new services and use cases for existing services.

So everyone that logs in, and gets a test drive, and gets a Citrix ID in Workspace Cloud -- they are going to be a great channel for driving demand on existing services and introducing new services very efficiently as well. So you will see that as well. So it's streamlining, but it's also -- it's streamlined in terms of the number of things, but also to go to market on some of them, as well.

STEVE ASHLEY, ANALYST, ROBERT W. BAIRD & COMPANY, INC.: Steve Ashley, Robert Baird. I wanted to go back to the Citrix Workspace Cloud. If we look down the road to when a company were to adopt it, if we were to look at the IT administration -- the number of people who today are working to deliver MDM, to deliver XenApp, to deliver all the separate pieces -- once this is all allocated and put together, how does that change? Is there an element of operational efficiency that comes with this story?

MARK TEMPLETON: Yes. It's about 20 to 1. So the testing that was done in the form of screen time -- that's how we have measured it, all right? So the same --

DAVID HENSHALL: Some of the material that got pulled from the notes this morning. (laughter)

MARK TEMPLETON: So think of it that way, Steve, on certainly a XenApp or a XenDesktop basis. So an hour of screen time to do it on Workspace Cloud versus 20 hours of screen time to do it in the traditional way.

BILL BURLEY: It will also reduce the level of the person who can administer. So it starts to broaden our ability to have more customers taken care of, and then your high-end folks can be doing different things in the company.

STEVE ASHLEY: Then I just wanted to go back to be installed base of XenApp. And I know you guys are working to get even stronger and more automated tools out there. What is the prospects for getting more powerful tools into the market and helping the customer base migrate? And what is your expectation about the timing of when we might see them be coming over to 7.6?

BILL BURLEY: As I said earlier, I think we're doing a few things to help that. And some of it are tools, as you said, like our Project Serenity, and then automating it with our lifecycle management technology. I think I said earlier, we've had 36,000 apps already migrated. And then we are able to add what I'll call the automation on top of that.

So this is before we even got to the recipes or the blueprints. So we have got a combination of these tools, and they're services. So they are not, like, things I have to download, and it's always here -- services I can use to migrate or upgrade. And you combine that with our StoreFront 3 strategy, I could start to layer in multiple versions and move people over at my pace.

And that was one of the reasons why we extended the 6.5 through 2017. Because now, customers have a way to migrate at their pace in an efficient, predictable way. Sometimes migrations -- you lose predictability when the human element isn't always exact. But now, with the recipes and the blueprints and the migration services, you are going to get a lot more predictable migrations. And then they move at a rate they can consume versus this forklift concept.

MARK TEMPLETON: Just one thing to add, Steve, and that is -- and this sort of ties back to the last question, as well -- is one of those technologies that has been tougher to go to market with in terms of the cost of sale, etc., is this technology we acquired a few years ago called AppDNA. And so tomorrow -- I don't know if you all are going to come to the keynotes tomorrow -- you will hear Juan Rivera, who is on Bill's team, talk about something called AppDisks.

DAVID HENSHALL: We talked about it earlier.

MARK TEMPLETON: Okay, you did. Good. So there's an example of pulling several technologies together, turning them into a cloud service, and accelerating a customer's ability to move apps to the virtual infrastructure. So I'm particularly excited about what we are doing there. And there's a competitive aspect of that, you know, with VMware, but also there's a big customer aspect in terms of the cost and speed of moving from physical to virtual.

BILL BURLEY: Then your ability to manage many less images. And so combining AppDNA, which can validate how it should get delivered with AppDisk, which is one desktop image, and be able to insert the apps that matter to the users based upon who they are, is just going to be vastly better and accelerate adoption on that side.

RAIMO LENSCHOW, ANALYST, BARCLAYS CAPITAL: Raimo Lenschow from Barclays. So we are seeing a lot of product innovation coming out and a lot of change at your organization. If you think about where are you in terms of -- let's do a baseball game -- in terms of innings? In terms of having the right portfolio in place to kind of be able to reaccelerate the growth?

And then a question for Carlos as well: at the moment -- when you kind of started your job, how much was -- was there a sales issue? And how much was there a product issue? So when you went in there, were you the problem solver? Or is it at the moment predominantly on the product side? Thank you.

MARK TEMPLETON: What inning are we in? It depends on which element you are talking about, I think. From a pure restructuring point of view, we are through the announcements. All the players are on the field, and we just need to play out the rest of the game. That will take the balance of this year. I think we progressionally get better over that period of time.

In terms of a portfolio of products, I think the portfolio at a high level is in place. I think we have got the capabilities that we need. There's always innovation, integrations, things that we can do to make it better, more integrated, easier to consume, etc. And that's the journey that we will always be on. But in terms of the larger elements and the big pieces, I think we've got -- I think we really have those pieces in place right now.

CARLOS SARTORIUS: My side? So basically, I think that if you look into what's the difference between the priorities that we had in 2014 to 2015 as the focus, and I think that both on the sales side as well as on the channel side, we're trying to be very, very clear where we want people to focus; what's the strategy; how we want to get it done.

Because I think that there was a lot of attention paid to a number of other products. We were doing many different things. And what we wanted to do is be very, very clear: this is the strategy. We are going to be focusing on those three specific areas that I showed.

We want to put the structures behind it so that we are sure we understand what our sales force will do, what the expectations are, right -- how we are going to compensate them at the same time with the channel. And this is why you are seeing the specialization with the channel, all the enablement work that we are doing with the channel.

So I think it's -- to make sure that we all know strategy, those products, go after it, what's the structure, how we measure success. And then just measure and drive it. That's basically what we are trying to do.

MARK TEMPLETON: Right.

CARLOS SARTORIUS: And it was a lot of work last year to set it up, and this year it's in place.

JERRY MAJETICH, ANALYST, DREXEL HAMILTON: Jerry Majetich, Drexel Hamilton. You were talking about global expansion, and the cloud pretty much covers the globe. Are there any countries or regions that may cause problems with regulations or policies and make operations difficult and/or a security concern?

MARK TEMPLETON: Well, let's see. Maybe I can try to take that one. So the answer is -- you know, we are under the same sort of geopolitical environment that everyone that is of any size as an American tech company is, especially in China and in Russia today. We've been, I think, pretty clear about that. I don't think there are security issues there; I just think there are realities to the geopolitics in those countries -- that we have seen our business change. Because, frankly, we -- like in Russia, we've done a fair amount of business with government agencies. Like, big rail system runs on Citrix.

So then from a cloud perspective, as we talked about this morning, the control plane doesn't really contain the kind of persistent data that anyone cares about. I mean, that's the only way you can actually make a strategy like that work. And the resource zone is where the persistent data is. Now, so you can basically point Workspace Cloud at any hypervisor, basically, if you saw the list that came up, or cloud -- you know, kind of acknowledged Cloud Platform.

And so to the degree that in those countries where there are security and IP concerns, or whatever they are, everything can be located on a geographic-specific basis. And we think we are doing the right things to allow the monitoring and measurement, etc., for compliance.

And that, I think, is a universal issue across all countries. And so I don't think there's anything particularly unique around security in any of these markets. It's more a geopolitical issue, I'd say.

And there, I think we are, like a lot of companies, trying to figure our way through it. What do we do in Russia? What do we do in China? How long will these things go on? I think we have to assume that this kind of environment is going to go on for a long time. So we are rethinking our partnering and how we do partnering in those countries right now -- assuming that this is going to go on for a while.

CARLOS SARTORIUS: If I just add -- it's not just those countries. In some other countries where we have implemented mission-critical systems, we have been working very close with the regulatory entities there to ensure that that's the case. And in particular, I mentioned about some examples -- I cannot say the name, who they are; but nationwide, mission-critical systems, either for a Minister of Interior, for public safety, for a number of different uses.

And we have been able to work with the legislation and with the regulatory entities to actually be able to do it. So I think as long as the architecture, as Mark described, allows them to achieve the way they would like to see the protection of data or the protection or control of the architecture in the system -- I think that we should be all right.

MARK TEMPLETON: I think we have time for one more question.

SANJIT SINGH, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Sanjit Singh, Morgan Stanley. I wanted to get your thoughts on how you are thinking about the delivery networking business -- NetScaler, maybe the non-NetScaler part of the business? You talked about the three segments: enterprise, telco, and your cloud customers being quite lumpy.

Do you see the trajectory of growth as something that can accelerate from current levels? It has come down over the last couple of years. Some of that is the market. But if you do see that as at a potential of accelerating from current levels of growth, where in those segments -- enterprise, cloud -- do you expect to gain traction? Is it more from the sales force expansion that you are planning out with the investments? Or is it moving to lower parts of the market? How do you see that trajectory of growth?

KLAUS OESTERMANN: So I think if you look at -- take cloud service providers. There the plan is to expand the number of bigger providers that we have. So basically get revenue from all bigger partners instead of the current concentration we have.

On the telco side, it's simply a matter of our market share has been very small in telco. With the Bytemobile products, as I said, we've gotten into a lot of telcos and started getting quite a few projects. And now it's a matter of expanding with those telcos. And again, there's not that many telcos. So again, if we get -- the bigger telcos start really spending more wallet share with us on the ADC front, we will add -- so if you take the cloud and telco providers, the big guys are really big. So basically, adding more and bigger logos is part of the expansion strategy across those two segments.

For the enterprise space, it's a continued effort on really getting customers to start taking on and standardizing on STX. And there we are in a situation where F5 is the incumbent. And they've trained a lot of people that are running ADCs that they are the standard. They have a special language they like, and so forth.

So oftentimes that's an economical discussion, where it's like, well, how much money do you want to spend on this? And as you as you see that market or that budget grow for you, wouldn't it be smarter to do it this way? What we're seeing is oftentimes it's a tops-down decision, and then it gets implemented.

So we believe that in enterprise, there's quite a bit of growth for us in the core, head-on competition. And then when you look at Workspace delivery controllers, we can keep increasing the attach rates with the Workspace solutions. I think with what I talked about with NetScaler universal gateway -- that in and of itself is a pretty big -- if you look at the gateways that's been accumulated over time, per the analysts, that's probably a $400 million, $500 million spend a year. But now we believe there's actually going to be an acceleration, because people will be replacing a lot of products that they might not be betting on. They will be consolidating on fewer. So that market will grow.

So I think across the board, there's quite a bit of opportunity. And then as Carlos and I have alluded to, we are also looking at specific -- from a geocoverage model, where to expand. And then in the service provider market, where to expand the coverage as well. So plenty of opportunity.

CARLOS SARTORIUS: Just drive to it -- channel, channel, and more channel. That's one of the big initiatives that we have that we discussed yesterday with our partners is to really drive a lot of the networking business through our CSAs and distribution. Because we believe we have a great opportunity. We have put in place the specialization plus certain incentives for them to really drive it. And we believe that they will see that it's very interesting, and they will help us grow it.

MARK TEMPLETON: So I think we're out of time right now. But before we wrap up, I just want to say, again, on behalf of the Company, thank you very much for participating in this event today. Thanks for coming to Orlando for Citrix Synergy 2015. Special thanks to everyone who stuck with us on the webcast for the last five hours or so.

As I said a little bit earlier today, there's a lot going on in the organization right now. We are optimizing; we're streamlining; we're focusing. We are also innovating at the same time. And we're balancing those two main objectives pretty efficiently.

So we are working our way through the amount of churn in the organization right now. We feel pretty good about all the decisions we have made, and we are focused on execution from here on out. A lot of exciting news. Hopefully, those of you that are here in person, you spend the time -- go down to the exhibit floor. Talk to partners. Talk to customers. Talk to other employees. And just give you a much broader context into Citrix the business and how we are focused going forward. (Conference Instructions) So again, thank you very much, and thanks for joining us today.

urn:contentItem:5S9R-BF11-DXH2-6116-00000-00Citrix Systems Inc at Jefferies 2018 Global Technology Conference - Final2018-05-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:35ZLexisNexis051018a11502060.760Citrix Systems Inc at Jefferies 2018 Global Technology Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Eduardo Fleites

Citrix Systems, Inc. - VP of IR

Conference Call Participants

* John Stephen DiFucci

Jefferies LLC, Research Division - Equity Analyst

Presentation

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI, EQUITY ANALYST, JEFFERIES LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Listen. This is definitely -- sometimes you save the best for last. And we're -- this is going to be a fireside chat, and it's just something different here. But it's going to be a fireside chat. So Eduardo and I will sit up here and we'll talk about Citrix and how it's been evolving and how its markets have evolved. And we'll certainly open up to questions. And so be prepared in -- for the last 10 minutes or so, we'll open it up for Q&A.

Questions and Answers

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: So Eduardo, the first question I have -- and as you know, Synergy just happened 2 days ago. And the Analyst Day was in Anaheim, right? And Zach from my team was there, and Zach, we just had -- we had somebody reporting again tonight right now throughout -- so he's working on that. But Zach came -- he called me from there and we put out a note and then he said, "Something seems a little different this year." One of the things is it, it's just logical what Citrix is saying this year, is they're bringing the products together, now they fit together. So Eduardo, I'll let you expand on that. We wrote a note on it, and you can see the note. But just sort of it would have sort of a summary of what Citrix is doing right now. And it's not happening right now, but your approach to the market or maybe the approach that's happening.

EDUARDO FLEITES, VP OF IR, CITRIX SYSTEMS, INC.: Good afternoon. So Synergy is our partner, our annual partner conference. And this year we had it in Anaheim. Normally, we have our Analyst Day on the first day of our Synergy conference, which actually ends today. It's a 3-day event. So we have our Analyst Day usually at the conference because part of the issue is, don't listen to what we have to say directly, listen to what the customers are saying and do the demos, et cetera. So one of the biggest difference between this year's Synergy and previous 3, 4, almost every other Synergy, probably is that Synergy, historically, were a lot more visionary in terms of talking about what we will be building over the next 5 years. And we've always been great on vision and probably a bit slow on execution, if we had a fault. What's interesting about this year's Synergy is that everything we've been talking about for the past 4 or 5 years is already being sold today, or some of the features will be out over the next 60, 90 days. So the headwind on Citrix over the past few years is simply we've played in the virtual plain compute market. That market's growing in the low to mid-single digits. And again, it was always mostly a legacy app delivery type of conversation which is always hard because it's not a very fast-growing market, and the apps were moving in a different direction. Well, what we announced over the past 2 days is that everything we have done historically in terms of delivery, securely delivering legacy applications in terms of policies, whatnot, we're actually now doing it also for its assets. So now the conversation is not only about old, but how can we support a customer who still has plenty of old legacy applications that are expensive to rewrite but allowing for a user to sign on directly to all their apps, through the Workspace app, but at the same time, IT could not run policies across, not only the legacy apps but SaaS-based apps. And to give you an example, imagine a user, being Concur, Workday and Salesforce, and historically, you have to probably get every single SaaS app to create policies in terms of what type of employee from where, what location, which device can do download and not download or open certain information or whatnot. You can now actually put policies across all SaaS apps uniformly to save a lot time from an IT perspective. It can create watermarks in certain documents. There's been vendors who can do some of this, but then you'd been dealing with so many different vendors and you still have your legacy install base to deal with. So as of Tuesday, we officially do it for all apps. So the days of only talking about the past are all ended. And frankly, it's a much bigger TAM, it's a faster-growing TAM, and we are still -- we have a nice moat with our installed base and just we're talking basically based on about $100 a day -- a year per user. So just getting our installed base, a decent chunk of our install base, to get there it's a massive opportunity for Citrix. So basically, that's what we've been announcing over the past few days. We've looked at our website. We have the Analyst Day webcast and all the press releases regarding these products.

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: I guess the question coming up with -- in my mind, anyway, on your description, I'm trying to think of the application of the technology you're talking about. And previously, as you said, the number one use case was, hey, listen we have this legacy. When I say legacy, it doesn't mean mainframe. It means legacy client/server app like FileNet, something like that. And like an example that I knew of was the New York State lottery and filed it as a server-based technology. One person would have to access the app, and they wanted the whole department to access it. So they use Citrix to do that. That's the primary use case of Citrix. You all have probably used it as remote access, but really that's the prior use case. So now...

EDUARDO FLEITES: I noticed number one is Chromebook, which you all use, that's all being delivered by -- produced on Citrix.

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: But now you're saying, okay, we're going to expand that and you can use it for everything. But I guess my -- a question that comes in my mind is why would I even -- why would I need to do that? Like why do I -- like -- for a SaaS app, I just access the Internet and I connect to the Internet and I can connect to whatever -- Salesforce.com or whatever that is.

EDUARDO FLEITES: Yes. That's the problem because now IT doesn't know what you're doing. We have all -- you probably have regulatory issues, whether it's a SaaS app or not a SaaS app, okay? So the issue is about securing, controlling regulations -- that seems to be the equation -- we've always done but Citrix -- the conversations already -- probably are in remote access. The reality is, yes, that's what we do but it has to comply with all the innovations out there. So the issue is, do you want an employee who is disgruntled download all the files from Salesforce without you knowing, number one? In some cases, that's going to become a privacy issue, especially in Europe nowadays. So how are you addressing all those use cases?

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: Okay. That makes sense, and that also makes sense why you probably won't want to do any more dinners with the kids eventually. Actually just real quickly too, I was -- I remember after September 11, my employer at the time was certainly dislocated and everybody was remotely working or even we were working from other offices. But we're using VPN technology, and we went from one VPN to another. And then finally, we said, let's just go to Citrix because they actually provide better security than the VPN we were using, and it gives us more flexibility, and that's what we did. So that makes a ton of sense to me. Okay. That sounds really interesting. Sticking with sort of the Workspace Services world, and it's something I always ask you because we had a call on Citrix a while ago when the world brought the vision, which about desktop virtualization, which is going to be this huge market. It's certainly a market. It just probably didn't evolve to what people thought it would at that time. And the reason why we didn't think it would is not because it didn't make sense. It does make sense. But because the world just wasn't ready for it. We were like, listen, it's just too hard to do, and once you do it, the experience isn't that great for the users. So it's probably not going to see the kind of broad deployment that some people expected. And that sort of seems like what happened. The rules changed, right? So networking technology is, number one, cheaper and better; and storage technology is, number one, cheaper and better; and those are 2 of the things that were issues. And I just wonder I'd love to make the other call too. And you know what, this market is going to take off now because the world's ready for it and Citrix is -- there's more competition than it used to be, but you're still a leader, if not the leader. So I guess, how do you think about that market? I think it's smart not to, like, talk about it because that would turn investors off because we'll read their memories, but I still wonder on that. Like I don't want to miss that.

EDUARDO FLEITES: It's interesting, and obviously, I love to joke that when you look at industry analyst reports, when talking about the companies that have been in business 5 years or greater, talking about the size of the market, and they're pretty spot on in terms of the 3-, 4-, 5-year growth rates. When it's something totally new, they tend to be totally off. Desktop was one, and the mobility one was the other one that was going to be a massive market in 5 years. And then you look historically, nothing has sort of grown that quickly. So I just get very cynical with age, I guess. The desktop thing was interesting. It was great because everybody was bringing their iPads. You had all these tablets coming out, iPhones, Android devices. And then how do you use your legacy apps, opening it up and get your full desktop, it's great. So we started playing with it internally, and then you realize your finger is too big to do a full desktop on these devices. The reality is you just want to open up one app at a time, just like you do now with iTunes whatnot, and you do your work, close it, open up another app. The reality within desktop at Citrix, when I open it up, it depends how you configure it. The way we configure internally at Citrix is you can look at it -- do you want to look at your favorite apps or do you want to look at it the full desktop. Obviously, when I open up certain devices, I look at the apps. And then when I have my full desktop, I just open a full desktop. Unfortunately, not everybody would configure XenDesktop that way. So then they're like, I'm getting a full XenDesktop on my iPhone. It's crazy. It doesn't work. Can you read it, right? And to think, finally, it was so expensive in terms of the storage standpoint, client devices. You still didn't even have $80 dollars in clients back then. Storage was still very expensive. So the conversation was only with a CCO, which is not the greatest conversation you want to have when you sell. As all those devices started coming down, a lot of people started writing different types of applications, SaaS apps. So that kind of convoluted the conversation as well. We started growing a little faster. However, the conversation is moving to non-legacy type of applications. So well, basically, we were going -- we were missing probably a year or 2 years behind the curve. The market finally caught up to where we want it to be. Our technology finally caught up where we want it to be in terms of SaaS apps, et cetera. And even analytics, like one of the plays obviously has to be -- we've always had security features in products with Citrix, but we're not -- we don't call ourselves a security -- we're not a network security company, but we were one of the largest SWPM in terms of sales and Android units for many, many years. We've bundled it with our networking so we never sold it separately anymore. We've always set out firewalls. So in that area, we're always pretty invested from an R&D perspective. The one piece that we have now with analytics is with all these workloads and all these touch points you have which are filed -- and actually you have that in mobile, and all that flows through and [that's gave a ready feed,] and now we have an SD-WAN, and with that access, we look at the traffic management. We have a ton of information to do analytics, and to give you one example, are we necessarily a pure-play private security company? No. But -- so let me give you an example, with the new products that we have with the Workspace app, you can actually tell -- so if you put policies across, say, Concur, Workday and Salesforce, whatever, you know somebody used Concur to do their work, travel, and they're supposed to be here at the Jefferies conference. Yet you figured that somebody is logging in from the Miami office. Well, I'm supposed to be here, who's using my name to log in? Right there, you can do it. You're putting policies across several SaaS apps, use the information and look at how do I log in all the time, what do I use, what files do I download, and then you can realize whether, hey, should I look into this person or not -- there's something weird, did they lose their phone or whatnot? So this is -- all that data flows to Citrix. And by the way, it's encrypted by Citrix, so we can actually look into the encryption to see what's happened. So there is a security play, an analytics play that can be used in many, many different ways. And now if you can do it for all SaaS and legacies, that's a lot of information we can use, or the company will use on the other hand.

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: Okay. That's interesting. That's actually really interesting. I'm going to ask one more and then I'm going to open it up to the audience. And I'm going to now go to NetScaler, the networking business. That performed really well from late 2015 and most of 2016. And then it didn't perform as well, and it's been evolved for business and primarily because there's -- some of the large Internet companies that you sell to and were made by it. I guess should we start to think of that any differently going forward? Is there any way to smooth that business out? Or is that just it is what it is, and that's what we live with or you live with?

EDUARDO FLEITES: I live with the questions. There is a way of smoothing it out, and the way to smooth it out is to make the enterprise a bigger chunk of it. The SSD is probably where they are and they tend to buy about a little about a few million every quarter. They'll buy $40 million in one quarter a year. Last year, it didn't happen. They -- one of them might be -- some of them overbought the last Q4 prior, and they're building up. They use -- probably used capacity and they buy again. What we did do 2 years ago is we hired another 60, 70 salespeople focusing on the enterprise of the business. And that keeps the business growing materially. Last year, and even in Q1, it grew at 20% in terms of bookings year-over-year. Now the SSPPs (sic) [SSP], the large onetime buyers, also grew 20% in Q1 but it's very lumpy. Now I would argue it almost derisked the year because it happened in Q1 instead of Q4 this year. So it's not something -- now you have to wait to see what happens. But yes, our Q2 is always very lumpy because of that percentage. Now the SSP lumpy piece of the business of NetScaler ADC is usually about 30% of bookings. So what we're really talking about is 30%. The other 70% is growing just as fast and becoming a bigger piece. So while it'll still be lumpy, it is becoming less lumpy as our enterprise business grow. Now we also have NetScaler SD-WAN. We have NetScaler Analytics. Though there's a lot of our networking products now, the focus is still ADC. What's interesting in the ADC front is that we are -- on the enterprise side, we also have a new model on selling, which is a full capacity model. So basically, even though some of -- we do have a pure software version only, but the one that comes in appliance, you can pick the appliance and then you take per usage capacity and you still have the software piece. So if you have multiple data centers, you're only paying on the capacity since you cost from data centers. So it's almost like we're also selling the subscription version of NetScaler now. We can create some headwinds in terms of recognized revenue as well.

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: That's in appliance form.

EDUARDO FLEITES: It's -- we have a pure software, but there's also -- yes, there's a download for that, but it's appliance form.

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: Because most people would have a hard time getting there with an appliance. Okay. And how's the adoption of customers? You've said about how much of that business is...

EDUARDO FLEITES: We had 2 very large deals last year, and because of those deals, we realize that there's a demand for it. So really only one quarter this year but there are very large customers who are buying. So they're not small deals, they're $100 million deals.

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: So are these the Internet service providers?

EDUARDO FLEITES: No. These are other big tech companies.

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: Okay, interesting. Any questions from the audience? Okay.

EDUARDO FLEITES: That's what happens when you have the last meeting.

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: I have 2 more. So Citrix has seen a lot of change in the last couple of years, and you guys have an (inaudible) investor involved. And some of -- the stocks done pretty well. And some of it was probably things that needed to be done at the company as far as more tactical things. But when we start to think from here, because it seems like there's less of, I'll call it, cleanup stuff that needs to get done at Citrix at this point, from here, I'm just curious as -- how do I ask a question about -- what else can be done? Is there anything else that can be done, just the issue with dividend? These are really interesting too. Can you talk a little bit about that? Those -- are there any other things that can be done to return value to shareholders other than just growing the business?

EDUARDO FLEITES: So we've had several instructions over the past 2 years. You want to go back to the history of Citrix? It was a one-product company. Everybody said, you have one product. A large software company is going to take you out because they're going to sell that product and you're going to disappear. I still sometimes get that question, but we (inaudible) to an M&A. We brought in an M&A team and they built an amazing portfolio. They went a little overboard on building this massive portfolio of which certain products and businesses were not growing. So basically, we cleaned the portfolio, focused only on what's really focusing on the strategy, which is delivery apps and data security. We flattened the R&D organization as well and engineering and the product side in terms of longer systems but actually you're building a full solution. We finalized most of the integration of the entire portfolio this week, in the announcements we made. So basically now, our R&D investment is getting a lot more output on newer things versus supporting old platforms. The -- and now we're doing the final transition to a subscription model of our legacy to a more hybrid and cloud type of model, which brings more multi-tenancy, which again lowering the cost of R&D, and it just continues to accelerate. There is still room and needs attention, things from R&D. There's going to be more room from sales and marketing as well. Think of it in terms of we're still selling some of the old and new. In 2, 3, years, maybe you can start culling some of the tech support in the old platforms. And as you start getting more scale on the cloud, it becomes more of a repetitive sales motion, not necessarily an expensive sales motion. So I still think we have room to go in terms of efficiency. And it just depends from the time of the transition to a subscription model.

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: Okay. Because this year, I believe, your guidance is for flat margins for 2018. But at the same time, the guidance is -- and I don't know if it's very specific, but it's moved to more subscription, which will have a suppressive effect on...

EDUARDO FLEITES: Correct. What we're seeing is this year is -- and maybe into Q1 next year, is a headwind of the new subscriptions. So for all those who don't know, basically, if you get a perpetual deal and now you're selling a subscription, there's a 2.5-year breakeven. So you now have a headwind from a revenue perspective. Gross margins, you might have a headwind of 50 to 100 bps because you're supporting now both the old and the new. And as you scale, and obviously, you more than make up the difference on the OpEx side.

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: Okay. Any questions in the audience? Okay. You mentioned some earnings proficiencies and you mentioned R&D, that sales and marketing is the area that, I think, was where the most churn was at one time. And Citrix is also very channel focused, sales and marketing go-to market. Can you talk a little bit about that? Because there always seems to me, anyway, that you were paying a channel and paying the salespeople as if they weren't working with the channel? So -- and is that kind of at the -- from a high level, is that kind of what you fixed? Because it's improved tremendously, but -- and where would those -- where would the room be beyond that?

EDUARDO FLEITES: So yes, we're mostly indirect channel reseller type of motion supported by sales engineers. And then we have our direct in certain market segments and certain customers. The biggest chunk was actually -- since it's a general sales force, they're selling 25, 30 products but really only 6 matters. So that sort of productivity, and that was one of the biggest gainers in terms of going from high 30s of the percentage of sales or the marketing now to low to mid-30s. As you move to more subscription, it becomes more of an automated motion. There's still savings there. There will have to be, I'm sure, an evolution on our partner front. We already have many that are focused to become more MSPs, selling the CSP type of motion, so managed service providers to add more value to customers. We have other flattening-type resellers who are learning how to move customers up to the cloud and manage the cloud for them. But over time, yes, the traditional reseller motion is going to have to change because less value means lower commission checks. So there's still room there as you go through this transition. This is a multi-year issue here. You're not going to -- there's still an uplift that we need, specialization to move people up to the cloud. But once we -- or once you start adding, I mean, I need 10 more people licensed, it's actually be something that should be easily transacted on our website.

JOHN STEPHEN DIFUCCI: Okay. So let's see if there's any more questions. I think we're just about out of time. Eduardo, thank you very much.

EDUARDO FLEITES: Thank you.
